[I feel a mix of resentment and sadness as I recite my titles.] Bran. Brandon Stark. The Prince of Winterfell.
[I feel a hint of joy thinking about my direwolf.] My direwolf. (smiles) Prince of the green.
[I feel conflicted about this separation.] Two, (sighs) and one.
[I'm frustrated and resentful, but I don't voice my thoughts.] (remains silent)
[I want to appease Jojen, but I'm also eager to return to Summer.] I will. I'll remember. I could go back and do it now, if you like. I won't forget this time.
[I'm resentful of Jojen's control over me, but I keep my thoughts to myself.] (remains silent, looking sullen)
[I hope this is a good story about knights.] Do you know any stories?
[I really want to hear a story now.] You could tell one. While we walked. Hodor likes stories about knights. I do, too.
[I wonder if this character is like Jojen.] Did he have green dreams like Jojen?
[Those abilities sound amazing.] I wish I could. When does he meet the tree knight?
[I'm scared, but I can't show it. I need to think of solutions.] What if they come out here?
[That makes sense, but I'm still worried.] For shelter.
[We need to quiet Hodor before he gives us away!] NO! (He shouts) NO HODORING!
[I have to do something! Maybe I can...] (He reaches out with his mind, attempting to warg into Hodor) Be quiet! (His voice is shrill and scared)
[I'm shocked and scared by what I just did.] (His eyes are wide with disbelief) What... what happened?
[I feel guilty for entering Hodor's mind without permission.] I didn't mean to, Hodor. I'm sorry. (He turns to Jojen) I didn't know I could do that.
[I want to be useful.] What about Summer? I could send him to scout.
[I'm nervous, but determined to help.] I... I think so. I'll try. (He closes his eyes, concentrating)
[Concentrating hard, trying to reach Summer] (His eyes move rapidly behind closed lids) I... I can see... Men. Many men. They're... they're gathered in the old inn. Talking. Arguing.

[Straining to maintain the connection] Too many to count. Dozens, at least. They... they're talking about... (His eyes snap open, fear evident) They know we're here. They're planning to search the tower at first light.

Bran Stark.profile:
Brandon Stark, commonly known as Bran, is a young, crippled boy with extraordinary abilities who plays a pivotal role in "A Storm of Swords." As the second son of Lord Eddard Stark of Winterfell, Bran's life takes a dramatic turn after a fall that leaves him paralyzed from the waist down. Despite his physical limitations, Bran possesses powerful psychic abilities, including greensight and the capacity to warg into animals and even humans.

Bran is described as a curious and intelligent child, with a penchant for climbing before his accident. His paralysis forces him to adapt, relying on others for mobility, primarily the gentle giant Hodor who carries him. Bran's character arc in the story revolves around his journey to understand and control his burgeoning supernatural powers while navigating the dangers of a war-torn Westeros.

Throughout the novel, Bran travels north with a small group consisting of the Reed siblings, Jojen and Meera, and Hodor. Jojen, who has prophetic dreams, serves as Bran's mentor in developing his psychic abilities, while Meera acts as a protector and caregiver. This journey is fraught with peril as they attempt to evade detection by hostile forces.

Bran's warging ability, which allows him to enter the mind of his direwolf Summer, becomes both a source of freedom and a challenge. He struggles with the temptation to lose himself in Summer's consciousness, enjoying the wolf's physical capabilities that he himself lacks. This internal conflict between his human identity and his wolf experiences forms a significant part of his character development.

As the group travels, Bran's leadership qualities emerge. He uses his knowledge of Old Nan's stories to guide them to safe havens and makes crucial decisions in moments of crisis. However, his youth and inexperience are evident in his occasional fear and self-doubt.

A pivotal moment in Bran's development occurs when he accidentally wargs into Hodor during a moment of panic, revealing the extent and potential danger of his abilities. This incident forces Bran to confront the ethical implications of his powers and the responsibility that comes with them.

Bran's journey is not just physical but also spiritual and psychological. He grapples with his role in the larger events unfolding around him, the nature of his abilities, and his identity as a Stark in a world where his family's power has been drastically reduced. His story in "A Storm of Swords" is one of growth, self-discovery, and the burgeoning of potentially world-changing powers.

plots.name: Brienne of Tarth
plots.description: A tall, strong, and unattractive woman warrior tasked with escorting Jaime.
plots.summary: Brienne is determined to fulfill her duty to Catelyn Stark by delivering Jaime safely. She remains stoic in the face of Jaime's taunts and proves to be a capable boat handler.

plots.name: Brienne of Tarth
plots.description: A large, unattractive woman warrior tasked with escorting Jaime.
plots.summary: Brienne is honorable and dutiful, constantly frustrated by Jaime's provocations. She struggles with her own insecurities about her appearance and role as a female warrior.

plots.name: Brienne of Tarth
plots.description: A warrior woman escorting Jaime, sworn to Catelyn Stark.
plots.summary: Fights Jaime in an intense sword duel, matching his skill and ultimately overpowering him, showcasing her strength and combat abilities.

plots.name: Brienne of Tarth
plots.description: A warrior woman sworn to Catelyn Stark, captured alongside Jaime.
plots.summary: Brienne protects Jaime during their journey and faces potential assault from their captors. She remains loyal to her oath to return Jaime to King's Landing.

plots.name: Brienne of Tarth
plots.description: A tall, ungainly woman warrior sworn to Catelyn Stark.
plots.summary: Brienne meets with Jaime to discuss Renly's death and her oath to find the Stark girls.

plots.name: Brienne of Tarth
plots.description: A tall, strong woman warrior sworn to Catelyn Stark.
plots.summary: Brienne receives Oathkeeper and the task to find Sansa Stark, demonstrating her continued loyalty to her oath.

conversations.name: Brienne of Tarth
conversations.thought: Brienne remains resolute in her duty to Lady Catelyn, determined not to let Jaime's provocations affect her. She struggles with anger at his insults while maintaining her composure. Her focus is on safely completing the mission, aware of the dangers that surround them.

conversations.name: Brienne of Tarth
conversations.thought: Brienne is determined to fulfill her duty despite her intense dislike for Jaime. She's constantly on guard, both physically and emotionally, wary of Jaime's provocations. Her strong sense of honor clashes with Jaime's cynicism, and she struggles to reconcile his actions with the ideals of knighthood she holds dear.

conversations.name: Brienne of Tarth
conversations.thought: I must subdue the Kingslayer without killing him, honoring my oath to Lady Catelyn. His skill is impressive, even in his current state. I can't let his taunts distract me from my duty. I need to use my strength to my advantage and end this quickly. The longer this goes on, the more dangerous it becomes for both of us in these war-torn lands.

utterances.message: [He's trying to manipulate me. I won't fall for it.] You'll wear your chains, Kingslayer.
[I won't let him get to me with his insults.] You will call me Brienne. Not wench.
[He's trying to equate his title with mine, but they're not the same.] Do you deny that you slew a king?
[I'll ignore his crude comments and focus on our task.] (continues rowing silently)
[I don't owe him any explanations, but perhaps this will shut him up.] My father is Selwyn of Tarth, by the grace of the gods Lord of Evenfall.
[I won't let him question my loyalty.] It is Lady Catelyn I serve. And she commanded me to deliver you safe to your brother Tyrion at King's Landing, not to bandy words with you. Be silent.
[If he won't be silent, I'll make it clear what I think of him.] Talk with Ser Cleos then. I have no words for monsters.
[Why is he asking me this? I must be cautious.] No. I was my father's only s—child.
[I won't let him provoke me.] (turns away, gripping her sword hilt)
[His apology seems insincere. I won't fall for it.] Your crimes are past forgiving, Kingslayer.
[He doesn't understand the gravity of his actions.] You've harmed others. Those you were sworn to protect. The weak, the innocent...
[I won't let him bait me with that insult.] My name is—
[I must control my anger. I won't stoop to his level.] You will not provoke me to anger, Kingslayer.
[I need to understand his motivations.] Why did you take the oath? Why don the white cloak if you meant to betray all it stood for?
[That's not good enough.] That is no answer.
[His taunts won't work on me. I must stay focused.] (grunts with effort)
[I won't let him distract me. I must end this quickly.] (grunts and attacks fiercely)
[I have him now. I must make him yield.] Yield! Throw down the sword!
[The pain is sharp, but I can't let him win.] YIELD!
[I must make him stop. I don't want to kill him.] Yield, or I'll drown you!

Brienne of Tarth.profile:
Brienne of Tarth is a towering, physically imposing woman warrior who stands out in the world of Westeros for her unconventional role and unwavering sense of honor. The only child of Lord Selwyn of Tarth, Brienne eschews traditional feminine roles in favor of martial pursuits, driven by a deep-seated desire to prove herself as a warrior and to fulfill her oaths.

Described as unattractive and mannish, Brienne's appearance is a source of ridicule and scorn from others, including Jaime Lannister, who frequently taunts her. However, her intimidating stature and exceptional combat skills make her a formidable opponent. Brienne's prowess with a sword is demonstrated when she holds her own against Jaime in a fierce duel, despite his reputation as one of the greatest swordsmen in the Seven Kingdoms.

Brienne's most defining characteristic is her steadfast commitment to honor and duty. Sworn to Catelyn Stark, she takes her oaths with the utmost seriousness, dedicating herself to the task of safely escorting Jaime Lannister to King's Landing. This unwavering loyalty often puts her at odds with the more cynical and morally ambiguous characters around her, particularly Jaime, whose actions as the "Kingslayer" she finds reprehensible.

Throughout their journey, Brienne and Jaime develop a complex relationship marked by initial antagonism that gradually evolves into a grudging respect. Their conversations reveal Brienne's struggle to reconcile her idealistic view of knighthood with the harsh realities of the world, as well as her insecurities about her appearance and role as a female warrior.

Brienne's arc in "A Storm of Swords" sees her facing numerous challenges, from navigating treacherous war-torn lands to protecting Jaime from the brutal Brave Companions. Her resilience and combat skills are put to the test, culminating in her receiving the Valyrian steel sword Oathkeeper from Jaime and being tasked with finding Sansa Stark. This mission represents a new chapter in Brienne's journey, one that will test her resolve and honor as she continues to navigate the dangerous world of Westeros.

Despite the ridicule and obstacles she faces, Brienne remains true to her principles, embodying the ideals of chivalry and honor in a world where such virtues are often scorned or abandoned. Her character serves as a stark contrast to the moral ambiguity prevalent in many of the story's other players, making her a unique and compelling figure in the rich tapestry of "A Song of Ice and Fire."

plots.name: Bronn
plots.description: Tyrion's sellsword companion, recently knighted.
plots.summary: Bronn provides Tyrion with information about recent events and helps him prepare to meet Lord Tywin.

Bronn.profile:
Bronn is a pivotal secondary character in "A Storm of Swords," the third installment of George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A sellsword by trade, Bronn's cunning and pragmatic nature have allowed him to rise from humble beginnings to a position of influence in King's Landing. Recently knighted for his valor during the Battle of Blackwater, Bronn continues to serve as Tyrion Lannister's loyal companion and confidant.

Physically, Bronn is described as a lean, dark-haired man with a weathered appearance, reflecting his life as a hardened mercenary. His most notable attributes are his quick wit, combat prowess, and an unwavering sense of self-preservation. Bronn's personality is marked by a dry, often cynical humor and a ruthlessly practical approach to life and loyalty.

Throughout the story, Bronn's relationship with Tyrion Lannister remains central to his character. As Tyrion's personal guard and friend, Bronn provides crucial support and information, as seen when he briefs Tyrion on the aftermath of the Battle of Blackwater. This includes details about Stannis Baratheon's defeat, the new Tyrell alliance with the Lannisters, and changes in the City Watch.

Bronn's motivations are primarily driven by self-interest and a desire for advancement. His actions consistently demonstrate a willingness to take calculated risks for personal gain, while maintaining a degree of loyalty to those who can further his ambitions. As the story progresses, Bronn's newfound status as a knight opens up new opportunities, adding depth to his character arc as he navigates the treacherous waters of King's Landing politics.

conversations.name: Brown Ben Plumm
conversations.thought: This siege is becoming more hopeless by the day. The sewers might be our only option, but it's a revolting and perilous plan. I'm reluctant to suggest it, given my past experience, but we're running out of alternatives. I hope someone else volunteers for this unpleasant task if the queen decides to pursue this strategy.

utterances.message: [I've seen what those gates can do. Best to warn them.] Did you see them bronze heads above the gates? Rows of harpy heads with open mouths? The Meereenese can squirt boiling oil out them mouths, and cook your axemen where they stand.
[Perhaps it's time to mention the sewers. It's a long shot, but we're out of options.] I know a way. Sewers.

[I hope she doesn't ask me to go down there again.] Great brick sewers empty into the Skahazadhan, carrying the city's wastes. They might be a way in, for a few. That was how I escaped Meereen, after Scarb lost his head. (makes a face) The smell has never left me. I dream of it some nights.

Brown Ben Plumm.profile:
Brown Ben Plumm is a seasoned sellsword captain in "A Storm of Swords," known for his pragmatic approach and wealth of experience. With a mixed heritage that includes Westerosi, Summer Islander, and possibly Targaryen blood, Plumm embodies the diverse and complex nature of mercenary life in Essos. His weathered appearance and world-weary demeanor hint at a life filled with numerous battles and close escapes.

Plumm's personality is characterized by a blend of practicality, cunning, and a dry sense of humor. He is not afraid to speak his mind, even in the presence of powerful figures like Daenerys Targaryen. His suggestions, while sometimes unpleasant, often stem from hard-earned wisdom and a keen understanding of survival in difficult circumstances.

A key aspect of Plumm's character is revealed during the siege of Meereen, where he proposes using the city's sewers as a potential infiltration route. This suggestion demonstrates his resourcefulness and willingness to consider unconventional tactics. It also hints at his colorful past, as he admits to having used this method to escape Meereen previously, an experience that left a lasting impression on him.

Brown Ben's role in Daenerys' war council showcases his value as an advisor with unique insights into the challenges of siege warfare and urban combat. His reluctance to volunteer for the sewer mission, should it be approved, reveals a self-preserving streak typical of long-surviving mercenaries.

While not a central character, Brown Ben Plumm's presence adds depth and realism to the complex world of mercenaries and military strategy in George R.R. Martin's epic fantasy. His practical advice and past experiences serve as a counterpoint to more idealistic or conventional military thinking, highlighting the gritty realities of warfare in the world of "A Song of Ice and Fire."

plots.name: Catelyn Stark
plots.description: Mother of Robb Stark, recently confined for releasing Jaime Lannister.
plots.summary: Catelyn is anxious about facing her son and the consequences of her actions. She is relieved when Robb forgives her but is shocked by his marriage announcement.

plots.name: Catelyn Stark
plots.description: Mother of Robb Stark, grieving for her own lost children.
plots.summary: Observes the scene with a heavy heart, drawing parallels between the dead squires and her own sons. She feels responsible for the deaths, as they were killed in retaliation for her release of Jaime Lannister.

plots.name: Catelyn Stark
plots.description: Mother of Robb Stark, cautious and politically astute.
plots.summary: Catelyn advises Robb on how to handle the delicate situation with the Freys, emphasizing the importance of guest right. She remains vigilant and observant of potential threats.

plots.name: Catelyn Stark
plots.description: Mother of Robb Stark, attending her brother Edmure's wedding at the Twins.
plots.summary: Catelyn grows increasingly suspicious during the feast. She realizes the betrayal too late and watches helplessly as her son and his men are slaughtered. In her final moments, she kills Walder Frey's grandson before her own throat is cut.

conversations.name: Catelyn Stark
conversations.thought: My heart races with anxiety and hope as I face Robb and his men. I'm torn between the guilt of my actions and the desperate love that drove them. I must explain myself, seek understanding, and bear whatever judgment comes. Above all, I yearn for Robb's forgiveness and pray my choices haven't irreparably damaged our cause.

conversations.name: Catelyn Stark
conversations.thought: Relief at Robb's forgiveness mingles with confusion over the presence of Lannister bannermen. I'm wary, wondering about their allegiance and Robb's intentions. My maternal instincts are on high alert, sensing something significant is about to unfold. I'm determined to understand the situation and protect our family's interests.

conversations.name: Catelyn Stark
conversations.thought: My heart is heavy with guilt and grief. These deaths are a direct result of my actions in releasing Jaime Lannister. I can't help but draw parallels between these dead squires and my own lost sons. I fear I've only complicated matters for Robb and brought more bloodshed upon us all. I must remain composed, but the weight of responsibility is overwhelming.

conversations.name: Catelyn Stark
conversations.thought: Anxiety grips me as we approach the Twins. The Freys are proud and easily slighted; we must tread carefully. I must guide Robb through this precarious situation, emphasizing the importance of guest right and cautious diplomacy. Our very lives may depend on how we handle this encounter.

conversations.name: Catelyn Stark
conversations.thought: Shock and horror consume me as I witness this brutal betrayal. My son, my firstborn, is in mortal danger. I must save Robb at any cost, even if it means sacrificing myself or others. Perhaps I can appeal to Walder Frey's fatherly instincts or sense of honor, though I know he has little. I'm prepared to beg, threaten, or bargain for Robb's life.

utterances.message: [I must remain strong and composed, despite my fears.] Your Grace, I have prayed for your safe return. I had heard you were wounded.
[Here comes the difficult part. I must address my actions.] The gods are good, then. (Takes a deep breath) They will have told you what I did. Did they tell you my reasons?
[The pain of loss wells up inside me.] I had five children. Now I have three.
[I must remain calm in the face of his anger.] Lord Rickard, the Kingslayer's dying would not have bought life for your children. His living may buy life for mine.
[Relief and gratitude wash over me.] If my heart led me into folly, I would gladly make whatever amends I can to Lord Karstark and yourself.
[I eye the strangers curiously, trying to understand their presence.] My lady, sers, are you new to my son's cause?
[I recall the house's allegiance.] [Westerling, yes. Their banner is six seashells, white on sand. A minor house sworn to the Lannisters.] (Nods politely)

[I respond courteously, still puzzled.] The honor is mine. [Can Robb have won the Crag's allegiance? If so, it was no wonder the Westerlings were with him. Casterly Rock did not suffer such betrayals gently.]
[Shock and disbelief overwhelm me.] [No, that cannot be, you are only a child. And besides, you have pledged another. Mother have mercy, Robb, what have you done?] (Stands in stunned silence)
[His words cut me to the core. I am responsible for this.] (remains silent, her throat dry)

[I must ensure Robb understands the gravity of this situation.] Tread lightly here, Robb. Lord Walder has a thin skin and a sharp tongue, and some of these sons of his will doubtless take after their father. You must not let yourself be provoked.

[He doesn't fully grasp the danger. I must insist.] If we are offered refreshment when we arrive, on no account refuse. Take what is offered, and eat and drink where all can see. If nothing is offered, ask for bread and cheese and a cup of wine.
[He's not listening. I need to make this clear.] Robb, listen to me. Once you have eaten of his bread and salt, you have the guest right, and the laws of hospitality protect you beneath his roof.
[My son is dying before my eyes. I must do something, anything to save him.] LORD WALDER! Enough, I say. You have repaid betrayal with betrayal, let it end.

[I'll threaten his grandson. Surely he cares for his family.] (pressing a dagger to Jinglebell's throat) Please. He is my son. My first son, and my last. Let him go. Let him go and I swear we will forget this... forget all you've done here. I swear it by the old gods and new, we... we will take no vengeance...
[Appeal to him as a father. There must be some shred of decency in him.] I take you for a father. Keep me for a hostage, Edmure as well if you haven't killed him. But let Robb go.
[I must convince him to leave, to save himself.] Yes. Robb, get up. Get up and walk out, please, please. Save yourself... if not for me, for Jeyne.
[There's no time. He must leave now.] Go to him. Now. Robb, walk out of here.

[This is my last chance. I must convince him.] (pressing the blade deeper into Jinglebell's throat) On my honor as a Tully, on my honor as a Stark, I will trade your boy's life for Robb's. A son for a son.
[No! NO! My son! My Robb!] (slashing Jinglebell's throat in anguish and despair)

Catelyn Stark.profile:
Catelyn Stark, née Tully, is a complex and pivotal character in "A Storm of Swords." A woman of noble birth and strong maternal instincts, Catelyn is the wife of Eddard Stark and mother to Robb, Sansa, Arya, Bran, and Rickon. Her fierce love for her children drives many of her actions throughout the story, often leading to far-reaching consequences.

Catelyn is described as having auburn hair and blue eyes, typical of House Tully. Her personality is marked by a keen political mind, unwavering loyalty to her family, and a deep sense of honor. These traits, however, sometimes conflict with each other, leading to difficult decisions and moral dilemmas.

As the mother of Robb Stark, the King in the North, Catelyn serves as both advisor and confidante. Her political acumen is evident in her cautious approach to alliances and her understanding of the complex dynamics between noble houses. However, her decision to release Jaime Lannister in exchange for her daughters demonstrates how her maternal love can sometimes override strategic considerations.

Catelyn's character arc in "A Storm of Swords" is marked by grief, guilt, and a desperate attempt to hold her family together. The loss of her husband and the believed deaths of her younger sons weigh heavily on her, influencing her actions and outlook. Her relationship with Robb is tested when he breaks his betrothal to the Freys by marrying Jeyne Westerling, a decision that Catelyn recognizes as politically disastrous.

Throughout the story, Catelyn remains vigilant and observant, often sensing danger before others. This is particularly evident in her unease during the events leading up to the Red Wedding. Her intuition proves tragically accurate, as she witnesses the betrayal and murder of her son and his men by the Freys and Boltons.

The Red Wedding marks the horrific culmination of Catelyn's arc. In her final moments, she desperately tries to save Robb by appealing to Walder Frey's sense of honor and offering herself as a hostage. When this fails, and she watches Robb die, Catelyn's actions become driven by grief and madness. She kills Walder Frey's grandson before her own throat is cut, ending her life in a moment of profound tragedy and injustice.

Catelyn Stark's journey in "A Storm of Swords" is one of loss, political maneuvering, and ultimately, heartbreaking sacrifice. Her character embodies the complexities of motherhood, duty, and honor in the brutal world of Westeros, making her a central and deeply affecting figure in the narrative.

plots.name: Cersei Lannister
plots.description: Queen Regent, Tyrion's sister.
plots.summary: Participates in the council, showing charm to some lords while expressing disdain for others.

plots.name: Cersei Lannister
plots.description: Queen Regent mourning her son Joffrey's death.
plots.summary: Cersei reunites passionately with Jaime but shows signs of fear and mistrust. She accuses Tyrion of Joffrey's murder and asks Jaime to kill him.

plots.name: Cersei Lannister
plots.description: Jaime's twin sister and lover, Queen Regent of the Seven Kingdoms.
plots.summary: Cersei attempts to seduce Jaime and gain his support against their father's plans, but is rebuffed.

conversations.name: Cersei Lannister
conversations.thought: I must assert my authority as Queen Regent while navigating the delicate balance of power. Father's presence complicates matters, but I can't appear weak. I'll support our victories and challenge any perceived slights to the crown's authority. Littlefinger's scheme bears watching – it could shift alliances in unpredictable ways.

conversations.name: Cersei Lannister
conversations.thought: I'm overwhelmed with grief for Joffrey and fear for my own safety. I've been longing for Jaime's return, but now I'm uncertain about his ability to protect me. I'm desperate for vengeance against Tyrion, whom I believe killed Joffrey. I need to convince Jaime of Tyrion's guilt and secure his promise to kill our brother.

conversations.name: Cersei Lannister
conversations.thought: Desperation fuels my visit to Jaime. I need his support against our father's plans to send me away from Tommen. I'm prepared to use seduction and emotional manipulation to sway Jaime, confident in my power over him. Fear for my son's future and anger at being sidelined drive my actions.

utterances.message: [I must appear strong and decisive.] He ought to be offering fealty. By what right does he call himself king?
[I need to control this situation before Joff makes a fool of himself.] (smiles nervously) A jest. Joff did not mean it.
[My brother is finally here, but why didn't he come sooner?] Jaime? Is it truly you? You should have come sooner. Why couldn't you have come sooner, to keep him safe? My boy...
[He looks so different. What happened to him?] You look so thin. And your hair, your golden hair...
[Gods, his hand! What happened?] (Eyes widen) The Starks...
[I don't know that name. Why is he telling me this now?] Who?

[I can't focus on this now. Joffrey is dead and I need Jaime's help.] (Turns to Joffrey's bier) He killed him, Jaime. Just as he'd warned me. One day when I thought myself safe and happy he would turn my joy to ashes in my mouth, he said.

[He doesn't believe me. I need him to understand.] For a whore. (Clutches Jaime's good hand) He told me he was going to do it. Joff knew. As he was dying, he pointed at his murderer. At our twisted little monster of a brother. (Kisses Jaime's fingers) You'll kill him for me, won't you? You'll avenge our son.
[I need to appeal to his love for me and our children.] Jaime, won't you talk to him? Father's made it clear that I am no longer wanted on the council.
[His stubbornness frustrates me.] Must you be so stubborn? All he wants...

[I need to make him see the urgency of the situation.] That need not be so terrible. He is sending me back to Casterly Rock as well. He wants me far away, so he'll have a free hand with Tommen. Tommen is my son, not his!

[His indifference angers me.] He is a boy! A frightened little boy who saw his brother murdered at his own wedding. And now they are telling him that he must marry. The girl is twice his age and twice a widow!
[I'll remind him of his fatherhood.] He is your son...

[His rejection infuriates me. I'll try to seduce him.] (She pushes up his tunic and fumbles with his breeches) Jaime, don't you think I want it as much as you do? It makes no matter who they wed me to, I want you at my side, I want you in my bed, I want you inside me. Nothing has changed between us. Let me prove it to you.

[His rejection wounds my pride and ignites my anger.] Was it your hand they hacked off in Harrenhal, or your manhood? I was a fool to come. You lacked the courage to avenge Joffrey, why would I think that you'd protect Tommen?

[I'll leave him with one final barb.] Oh, an angry cripple. How terrifying. (She laughs bitterly) A pity Lord Tywin Lannister never had a son. I could have been the heir he wanted, but I lacked the cock.

Cersei Lannister.profile:
Cersei Lannister, the Queen Regent of the Seven Kingdoms, is a complex and ambitious figure in "A Storm of Swords." Twin sister and lover to Jaime Lannister, Cersei is a striking beauty with golden hair, embodying the Lannister family's wealth and power. Her core motivation is the protection and advancement of her children and her own position, often resorting to manipulation and cunning to achieve her goals.

As the mother of King Joffrey and later Tommen, Cersei fiercely guards her influence over the throne. Her personality is marked by paranoia, ruthlessness, and a deep-seated fear of losing power. She harbors a particular hatred for her younger brother Tyrion, whom she suspects of plotting against her and her children.

Throughout the story, Cersei's relationships are fraught with tension. Her incestuous bond with Jaime becomes strained upon his return to King's Landing, as she struggles to accept his changed appearance and priorities. Her interactions with her father, Tywin Lannister, reveal her frustration at being sidelined in political decisions, especially regarding her children's futures.

Cersei's political acumen is evident in small council meetings, where she alternates between charm and disdain to influence outcomes. However, her impulsiveness and emotional reactions often undermine her effectiveness. The death of her son Joffrey marks a significant turning point, intensifying her paranoia and desire for vengeance.

As the story progresses, Cersei's character arc shows her growing increasingly isolated and desperate. She attempts to manipulate Jaime into supporting her against their father's plans, using seduction and emotional appeals. Her failure to secure Jaime's unconditional support highlights her waning influence and the erosion of her most trusted alliances.

Cersei's actions and decisions are consistently driven by her desire to maintain control over the Iron Throne and protect her remaining children. Her fierce maternal instinct, combined with her political ambitions, makes her a formidable and unpredictable player in the game of thrones, willing to go to extreme lengths to secure her position and legacy.

plots.name: Chett
plots.description: A bitter member of the Night's Watch, former steward to Maester Aemon.
plots.summary: Chett is the mastermind behind the mutiny plot. He resents losing his position to Samwell Tarly and dreams of becoming a lord or king among the wildlings after deserting.

conversations.name: Chett
conversations.thought: I'm seething with resentment and eager for the mutiny to begin. Tonight, I'll finally have my revenge on those who've wronged me, especially that pathetic Samwell Tarly. I must keep these fools in line until we can act, or everything will fall apart. Freedom and power await if we succeed.

utterances.message: [This cold is unbearable. I can't wait to be rid of this place and these people.] There's no bear here. Just an old print, that's all. Back to the Fist.

[These fools will ruin everything if I don't keep them in line.] We been over this. The Old Bear dies, and Blane from the Shadow Tower. Grubbs and Aethan as well, their ill luck for drawing the watch, Dywen and Bannen for their tracking, and Ser Piggy for the ravens. That's all. We kill them quiet, while they sleep. One scream and we're wormfood, every one of us.
[Not this nonsense again. Why is he so fixated on that damned bird?] What bloody bird?
[I don't have time for this idiocy.] Who bloody well cares? Kill the bird too if you like.
[I better calm him down before he does something stupid.] Paul, when they find the old man lying in a pool of blood with his throat slit, they won't need no bird to tell them someone killed him.
[Anything to shut him up about that damned bird.] He's yours.
[These fools will get us all killed if they don't shut up.] Close your bloody mouths, both of you. We're almost to the Fist.

Chett.profile:
Chett is a bitter and resentful member of the Night's Watch, serving as a steward to Maester Aemon before being replaced by Samwell Tarly. This demotion fuels his deep-seated anger and drives his central role in planning a mutiny against Lord Commander Mormont and other officers during a ranging expedition beyond the Wall.

A cunning and ambitious man, Chett masterminds a plot to desert the Night's Watch, recruiting 14 other disgruntled brothers to his cause. His scheme involves killing key figures, including Mormont, and causing chaos by releasing animals to cover their escape. Chett's motivations stem from a desire for revenge, particularly against Samwell Tarly, and dreams of power – he envisions himself becoming a lord or even a king among the wildlings after deserting.

Chett's character is marked by his calculating nature and ability to manipulate others, as seen in his interactions with co-conspirators like the slow-witted Small Paul and the impatient Lark the Sisterman. He carefully plans the details of the mutiny, showing a ruthless pragmatism in deciding who must die to ensure their success.

However, Chett's plans unfold against the backdrop of a larger threat – the approach of a massive wildling army led by Mance Rayder. This looming danger adds urgency and complexity to Chett's mutiny plot, as the Night's Watch debates whether to attack or retreat.

Chett's role in "A Storm of Swords" serves to illustrate the internal strife within the Night's Watch and the desperate measures some are willing to take in the face of harsh conditions and perceived injustices. His character embodies the themes of betrayal, ambition, and the struggle for survival in the unforgiving world beyond the Wall.

utterances.message: [An opportunity to impress Daenerys with my wit.] And fat chests of gold, silver, and gemstones as well. Let us not forget the gemstones.

Daario Naharis.profile:
Daario Naharis is a charismatic and flamboyant sellsword who becomes a key figure in Daenerys Targaryen's inner circle. With his striking appearance, including a blue-dyed beard and gold mustache, Daario cuts a memorable figure in the Essosi landscape. As the captain of the Stormcrows, a mercenary company, he demonstrates both martial prowess and cunning leadership.

Daario's personality is marked by his boldness, wit, and open admiration for Daenerys. He often uses humor and charm to make his points, as evidenced by his quip about not forgetting the gemstones when discussing Meereen's wealth. This flirtatious behavior and his obvious attraction to Daenerys add a layer of complexity to the strategic discussions among her advisors.

In terms of plot involvement, Daario plays a significant role in Daenerys' campaign to conquer the slave cities. His military expertise and willingness to suggest daring strategies make him a valuable, if sometimes controversial, advisor. During the siege of Meereen, Daario participates in the strategic planning, offering insights and alternative perspectives to the more cautious approaches of advisors like Jorah Mormont.

Daario's motivations appear to be a mix of personal ambition, a genuine belief in Daenerys' cause, and romantic interest in the young queen herself. His loyalty, while strong, is often questioned by other characters due to his mercenary background. This tension between his apparent devotion and his unpredictable nature adds depth to his character and creates ongoing intrigue in Daenerys' court.

As the story progresses, Daario's influence on Daenerys grows, both as a military advisor and as a potential love interest. His presence often serves to highlight the conflicting demands of leadership, personal desire, and political necessity that Daenerys must navigate as she pursues her goal of reclaiming the Iron Throne.

plots.name: Daenerys Targaryen
plots.description: The exiled queen of Westeros, known as the Mother of Dragons.
plots.summary: Daenerys inspects the Unsullied army, considering their purchase while struggling with the moral implications. She reflects on her past experiences and current desires, showing a mix of strength and vulnerability.

plots.name: Daenerys Targaryen
plots.description: The last surviving member of House Targaryen, seeking to reclaim the Iron Throne.
plots.summary: Daenerys negotiates with the slavers of Astapor to purchase all of their Unsullied, offering one of her dragons in exchange. She frees her new translator Missandei and contemplates the future of her army.

plots.name: Daenerys Targaryen
plots.description: The young queen leading an army to conquer Meereen and free its slaves.
plots.summary: Daenerys is determined to take Meereen despite the challenges. She considers various strategies and refuses to abandon the freed slaves. She narrowly escapes an assassination attempt.

plots.name: Daenerys Targaryen
plots.description: The young queen of Meereen, conqueror of the city and Mother of Dragons.
plots.summary: Daenerys grapples with the complexities of ruling Meereen, deals with diplomatic issues, and confronts her betrayers, showing both mercy and justice.

conversations.name: Daenerys Targaryen
conversations.thought: I'm torn between my desperate need for an army and the moral repugnance of slavery. The Unsullied's strength is undeniable, but at what cost? I must appear composed and regal, concealing my inner turmoil. How can I use this situation to my advantage without compromising my values? I need to gather more information while maintaining a facade of disinterest to keep the price down.

conversations.name: Daenerys Targaryen
conversations.thought: I'm torn between my determination to take Meereen and the reality of our dire situation. The lives of my people hang in the balance, and I must find a solution that doesn't sacrifice them needlessly. I need to project strength and decisiveness, even as doubts gnaw at me. The city's resources are vital for our survival and future conquests.

conversations.name: Daenerys Targaryen
conversations.thought: I'm torn between gratitude for their help and anger at their betrayal. I must appear strong and just, but I fear losing valuable allies. I need to address their past actions, assess their loyalty, and decide their fates. The truth about my father unsettles me, but I can't show weakness. I must navigate this carefully to maintain my authority.

utterances.message: [I must appear unimpressed to keep the price down.] They might be adequate to my needs. Tell me of their training.
[This is horrifying, but I must remain composed.] I call that madness, not courage.

[I must appear strong and decisive, even if I'm unsure.] I must have this city. Her granaries are full to bursting. There are figs and dates and olives growing on the terraces of her pyramids, and casks of salt fish and smoked meat buried in her cellars.
[Perhaps there's another way we haven't considered.] No weakness in the landward walls? Does that mean we might attack from the river or the sea?
[Recalling stories from my brother, I wonder if there are other options.] What if we were to build siege towers? My brother Viserys told tales of such, I know they can be made.
[I'm running out of options, but I can't give up.] (sighs) I will not throw away Unsullied lives, Grey Worm. Perhaps we can starve the city out.
[I must correct him. They are no longer slaves.] Freedmen. They are slaves no longer.
[Sewers? That's unexpected.] Sewers? What do you mean?

[I must appear strong and unforgiving, even if it pains me.] Be quiet. I will tell you when to speak. When I sent you down into the sewers, part of me hoped I'd seen the last of you. It seemed a fitting end for liars, to drown in slavers' filth.
[His insolence angers me, but he speaks some truth.] Be quiet. You helped win this city, and you have served me well in the past. But you lied, deceived me, betrayed me.
[This revelation shakes me, but I can't show weakness.] Viserys did. The Usurper called him that, the Usurper and his dogs. It was a lie.
[I must consider his words, despite my initial resistance.] So I am a coin in the hands of some god, is that what you are saying, ser?
[His honesty and loyalty move me, but I must test him further.] What if I decide you're only worthy to be my fool? Or perhaps my cook?
[His humility and loyalty have won me over.] (smiles) As you wish. Now kneel, and swear it to my service.

Daenerys Targaryen.profile:
Daenerys Targaryen, known as the Mother of Dragons, is a pivotal character in "A Storm of Swords." The last surviving member of House Targaryen, she is an exiled queen determined to reclaim the Iron Throne of Westeros. Daenerys is a young woman with striking purple eyes, a testament to her Valyrian heritage. Her journey from a vulnerable exile to a formidable conqueror is marked by her growing confidence, strategic acumen, and the unique bond she shares with her three dragons.

Throughout the book, Daenerys grapples with complex moral dilemmas, particularly regarding slavery and the use of force in her conquests. Her experiences in Astapor, where she acquires the Unsullied army, showcase her cunning and commitment to ending slavery. This decision marks a turning point in her campaign, providing her with a formidable fighting force while aligning with her ideals of freedom.

Daenerys's character is defined by a mix of compassion and ruthlessness. She shows mercy to the freed slaves, insisting on calling them "freedmen," yet displays unwavering resolve in her military campaigns. Her siege of Meereen demonstrates her tactical thinking and willingness to consider unconventional strategies, even as she wrestles with the human cost of her ambitions.

The young queen's leadership is tested as she faces betrayal from trusted advisors. Her confrontation with Ser Barristan Selmy and Ser Jorah Mormont reveals her capacity for both justice and mercy. She pardons Barristan after hearing his honest account of her father's madness, showing her ability to accept hard truths and value loyalty. However, her exile of Jorah for his past betrayals demonstrates that her forgiveness has limits.

Daenerys's journey is not just one of conquest but of self-discovery. She struggles with her awakening sexuality and the weight of her family's legacy. Her prophetic dreams, such as the one where she envisions herself as Rhaegar melting ice soldiers, hint at her potential role in larger conflicts to come.

As the story progresses, Daenerys evolves from a young girl sold into marriage to a confident ruler, making difficult decisions and shouldering the responsibilities of leadership. Her character embodies the complexities of power, the challenges of moral leadership in a harsh world, and the personal growth required to become a true queen.

utterances.message: [I need to explain the dangers of using the horn.] We free folk know things you kneelers have forgotten. Sometimes the short road is not the safest, Jon Snow. The Horned Lord once said that sorcery is a sword without a hilt. There is no safe way to grasp it.

Dalla.profile:
Dalla is a minor yet significant character in "A Storm of Swords," the third book in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. She is a wildling woman and the wife of Mance Rayder, the King-beyond-the-Wall. Though her physical appearance is not extensively described, Dalla is notably pregnant during the events of the book.

Dalla's most prominent attribute is her wisdom and knowledge of Free Folk lore and traditions. She demonstrates this during a crucial negotiation between Jon Snow and Mance Rayder, where she speaks about the dangers of using magical artifacts like the Horn of Winter. Her statement, "The Horned Lord once said that sorcery is a sword without a hilt. There is no safe way to grasp it," reveals her understanding of the risks associated with powerful magic.

As Mance Rayder's wife, Dalla plays a supportive role in the wildling leadership, offering insight and counsel. Her pregnancy during a time of great upheaval for the Free Folk adds a layer of vulnerability and urgency to the wildlings' situation. Though she doesn't take center stage in the negotiations, her presence and words carry weight, indicating her respected status among the Free Folk.

Dalla's role in the story, while brief, provides important context for the wildlings' motivations and the complexities of their culture. Her wisdom serves as a counterpoint to the more aggressive strategies proposed by some of the other wildling leaders, highlighting the diversity of thought within their ranks.

plots.name: Davos Seaworth
plots.description: The 'Onion Knight', loyal to Stannis Baratheon, survivor of the Battle of the Blackwater.
plots.summary: Davos returns to Dragonstone, determined to confront and kill Melisandre, whom he blames for the defeat and the death of his sons. He struggles with his injuries and the changed political landscape.

plots.name: Davos Seaworth
plots.description: A former smuggler turned knight, loyal to Stannis Baratheon.
plots.summary: Davos is imprisoned but remains loyal to Stannis. He resists Melisandre's attempts to convert him and disagrees with Lord Alester's peace proposal.

plots.name: Davos Seaworth
plots.description: The main character of this section, also called the Onion Knight.
plots.summary: Davos is released from his cell and brought before King Stannis. He observes the changes in Stannis and considers his precarious position.

plots.name: Davos Seaworth
plots.description: Stannis Baratheon's loyal advisor, known as the Onion Knight.
plots.summary: Davos observes the reactions to the news of Robb Stark's death and considers the implications of the Red Wedding.

conversations.name: Davos Seaworth
conversations.thought: Grief-stricken over the loss of his sons and the defeat at Blackwater, Davos is consumed by a mix of loyalty to Stannis and hatred for Melisandre. He's desperate for information about the battle's aftermath and his surviving family. Despite his injuries, Davos is determined to return to Dragonstone and confront Melisandre, whom he blames for the catastrophe.

conversations.name: Davos Seaworth
conversations.thought: Trapped and uncertain of his future, Davos grapples with conflicting emotions. He remains fiercely loyal to Stannis but harbors deep mistrust towards Melisandre and her foreign god. He's wary of her intentions yet can't deny her power. Davos clings to his faith in the Seven, seeking comfort in familiar beliefs while fearing the darkness that surrounds him.

conversations.name: Davos Seaworth
conversations.thought: Relieved to be free from his cell, but wary of the political situation. Concerned about his precarious position and loyal to Stannis, yet unsure of his standing. Anxious about the upcoming meeting with the king and suspicious of Ser Axell's motives. Determined to navigate the treacherous waters of court politics carefully.

conversations.name: Davos Seaworth
conversations.thought: Davos is deeply troubled by the brutality of the Red Wedding. He's silently processing the implications for their cause, concerned about the moral ramifications and potential consequences of such a shocking act. He's wary of how this might influence Stannis's decisions.

utterances.message: [I appreciate his warm welcome, but I must focus on more pressing matters.] I am no ghost, Salla. (coughs) I swam beneath the chain and washed ashore on a spear of the merling king. I would have died there, if Shayala's Dance had not come upon me.
[I need information more than comfort.] (after some time) How is it you come by a Pentoshi ship? Have you gone pirate again, my lord?
[I must know about the battle and my family.] I saw Black Betha burning, and Fury as well. Did none of our ships escape the fire?
[Relief floods through me, but I must focus on my duty.] The Mother is merciful. I must go to him, Salla. I must see him. (pauses) His Grace will give me a ship.

[I appreciate his offer, but I cannot abandon my king.] You are kind, Salla, but my duty's to my king, not your purse. The war will go on. Stannis is still the rightful heir by all the laws of the Seven Kingdoms.

[Melisandre's influence has grown stronger. I must act.] The red woman did this to him. She sent the fire to consume us, to punish Stannis for setting her aside, to teach him that he could not hope to win without her sorceries.
[My resolve hardens. I know what I must do.] (pulls out a dirk) I have a knife myself. Captain Khorane made me a gift of it. A knife to cut out Melisandre's heart. If she has one.
[I fear the darkness, but I must not show weakness.] No. Please.
[I must not let her manipulate me.] I need the torch.
[I cannot lie, even if it might save me.] No. You are the mother of darkness. I saw that under Storm's End, when you gave birth before my eyes.
[I must resist her temptations.] I want no part of you, my lady. Or your god. May the Seven protect me.
[I cannot abandon my faith so easily.] I have worshiped them all my life.
[A ship could be my salvation, but can I trust this man?] (Davos remains silent, studying Ser Axell's face)
[I must tread carefully here.] I hear. (Thinks to himself: And you dare name me traitor?)
[The brutality of this act is staggering. What kind of men would do such a thing?] (remains silent, looking troubled)

Davos Seaworth.profile:
Davos Seaworth, known as the "Onion Knight," is a former smuggler turned loyal advisor to Stannis Baratheon in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords." A man of humble origins, Davos rose to prominence through his unwavering loyalty and honest counsel. Physically marked by his past, with shortened fingers as punishment for his smuggling days, Davos carries both the scars and wisdom of his experiences.

Devoted to Stannis and his cause, Davos struggles with the aftermath of the disastrous Battle of the Blackwater, where he lost several of his sons. This tragedy deepens his character, adding layers of grief and determination to his already complex personality. Davos is characterized by his pragmatism, integrity, and a strong moral compass that often puts him at odds with the more ruthless or mystical elements in Stannis's court.

Throughout the story, Davos grapples with his mistrust of Melisandre, the red priestess who holds significant influence over Stannis. His skepticism of her magical practices and the foreign god R'hllor she serves creates tension and conflict, as he remains steadfast in his traditional faith in the Seven. This religious and ideological struggle becomes a central aspect of Davos's character development.

Davos's journey in "A Storm of Swords" is marked by significant trials, including imprisonment and threats to his life. Despite these hardships, he maintains his loyalty to Stannis and continues to offer honest, often unpopular advice. His ability to navigate the treacherous waters of court politics, despite his lowborn status, showcases his intelligence and adaptability.

As the political landscape shifts with events like the Red Wedding, Davos finds himself in a pivotal position, observing and influencing Stannis's reactions and decisions. His perspective provides a grounded, ethical counterpoint to the more extreme or mystical views of other advisors, making him a crucial voice of reason in Stannis's council.

Davos Seaworth embodies the complexities of loyalty, faith, and morality in the face of war and political upheaval. His character serves as a relatable anchor in the midst of the grand and often ruthless power struggles of Westeros, offering a unique perspective on the unfolding events and the nature of true service to a ruler.

plots.name: Donal Noye
plots.description: The one-armed blacksmith at Castle Black.
plots.summary: Noye helps Jon upon his return and provides information about the state of the Night's Watch and recent events.

conversations.name: Donal Noye
conversations.thought: The lad's in a bad way, but his information could be our only hope against the wildling threat. I'm torn between urgency to hear his report and concern for his condition. The recent betrayals weigh heavily on me, and I dread having to share more bad news with Jon.

utterances.message: [This confirms our worst fears.] How many, Jon? Who's leading them?
[The disgust is clear in my voice.] Garth of Oldtown, Ollo Lophand, Dirk... thieves, cowards and killers, the lot of them. We should have seen it coming.

Donal Noye.profile:
Donal Noye is a seasoned and resilient figure at Castle Black, serving as the one-armed blacksmith for the Night's Watch. Despite his physical limitation, Noye plays a crucial role in maintaining the fortress's defenses and supporting its inhabitants. His gruff exterior belies a sharp mind and unwavering loyalty to the Watch.

Noye's experience and pragmatism make him a valuable source of information and counsel, particularly during times of crisis. This is evident in his interaction with Jon Snow upon the young man's return from beyond the Wall. Noye demonstrates a keen understanding of the Watch's precarious situation, balancing the urgent need for intelligence about the impending wildling threat with concern for Jon's well-being.

His frank and straightforward manner is apparent in how he delivers difficult news, such as the betrayal and murder of Lord Commander Mormont. Noye doesn't mince words when describing the traitors, calling them "thieves, cowards and killers," revealing his strong sense of honor and disgust for those who break their vows.

Despite not holding an official leadership position, Noye's presence and actions suggest he is a respected figure within the Night's Watch. His role in tending to Jon and participating in discussions about the Watch's future indicates that he is trusted and valued for his judgment and experience.

Noye's character embodies the resilience and adaptability required of the Night's Watch, continuing to serve effectively despite his physical impairment. His presence at Castle Black during this tumultuous time highlights his importance to the order and his commitment to its mission of protecting the realm.

plots.name: Edmure Tully
plots.description: Catelyn's brother, betrothed to a Frey daughter.
plots.summary: Edmure is eager to meet his bride-to-be and somewhat impatient with the Freys' reception.

conversations.name: Edmure Tully
conversations.thought: This wedding feels more like a political negotiation than a celebration. I'm eager to meet my bride, but the Freys' cold reception unnerves me. I hope my marriage can help smooth over the tensions, but I fear the worst. I must stay alert and follow Robb and Catelyn's lead in this delicate situation.

utterances.message: [I need to make sure Robb understands the full extent of their crimes.] They murdered two of my men as well, to get into the tower. Delp and Elwood.
[I hope my bride isn't as unpleasant as some of these Freys.] When shall I meet my betrothed?

Edmure Tully.profile:
Edmure Tully is the younger brother of Catelyn Stark and the current Lord of Riverrun. As the heir to House Tully, he plays a significant role in the War of the Five Kings, though his actions often have unintended consequences. Edmure is described as good-hearted but often impulsive and naive, lacking the strategic acumen of his sister or father.

In "A Storm of Swords," Edmure's most pivotal moment comes with his arranged marriage to a daughter of House Frey, a union designed to mend the rift caused by Robb Stark's broken betrothal. This wedding becomes a focal point of tension and political maneuvering. Edmure approaches the marriage with a mix of duty and curiosity, eager to meet his bride despite the circumstances.

Edmure's relationship with Robb Stark is complex. As Robb's uncle and bannerman, he strives to support the King in the North, but his actions sometimes conflict with Robb's broader strategies. This is evident when Edmure reports the murder of two of his men during Lord Karstark's vengeful killing of Lannister squires, highlighting his concern for his own people.

Throughout the story, Edmure grapples with the weight of his responsibilities and the harsh realities of war. His character arc involves learning to navigate the treacherous waters of Westerosi politics, often finding himself caught between family loyalty and the brutal necessities of conflict. As the Stark forces arrive at the Twins for his wedding, Edmure's apprehension is palpable, reflecting his growing awareness of the precarious nature of alliances in this tumultuous time.

Edmure's actions and decisions, while often well-intentioned, frequently have far-reaching consequences that shape the course of the war and the fate of House Tully. His character serves as a poignant example of how even minor players can significantly impact the grand tapestry of power struggles in Westeros.

plots.name: Gendry
plots.description: A blacksmith's apprentice traveling with Arya's group.
plots.summary: Gendry is mentioned as one of Arya's companions, but his specific actions are not detailed in this excerpt.

plots.name: Gendry
plots.description: A young blacksmith apprentice traveling with Arya.
plots.summary: Gendry supports Arya during the confrontation, appearing dangerous in his chainmail and with a sword.

plots.name: Gendry
plots.description: A young blacksmith traveling with the group, unaware of his true parentage.
plots.summary: Gendry interacts with Arya, sharing his knowledge about Thoros of Myr and his experiences as an apprentice blacksmith in King's Landing.

plots.name: Gendry
plots.description: A young blacksmith, traveling with the Brotherhood.
plots.summary: Gendry becomes protective of Arya in the brothel, referring to her as his sister to ward off unwanted attention.

plots.name: Gendry
plots.description: A young blacksmith traveling with the Brotherhood.
plots.summary: Gendry decides to stay with the Brotherhood and offer his skills as a smith. He is knighted by Lord Beric, becoming Ser Gendry of the hollow hill.

conversations.name: Gendry
conversations.thought: I'm eager to share my knowledge about Thoros and life in King's Landing with Arya. Her interest intrigues me, and I wonder about her background. I feel a sense of pride in my expertise as a blacksmith apprentice, but also a hint of nostalgia for my former life. I'm curious about Arya's reactions and want to impress her with my stories, while also trying to understand her better.

conversations.name: Gendry
conversations.thought: I feel protective towards Arya in this dangerous environment. She's too young and innocent to be in a place like this. I need to shield her from unwanted attention without revealing her true identity. I'm also grappling with our class differences and my own conflicted feelings about our relationship.

utterances.message: [What's she on about now?] (Frowns) What are you talking about? They're just trees.
[How does she know these things?] (Skeptical) And how do you know which way is north or south?
[I need to show we're not defenseless.] (rides out from behind the cottage wall) She's not alone. Do like she says, and leave us be.
[I'm surprised Arya is interested in this.] This Thoros, is he the same Thoros who lived in the castle at King's Landing? A red priest, fat, with a shaved head?
[She seems to know more than she lets on.] He won't remember me, but he used to come to our forge. My master always scolded him about his flaming swords.

It was no way to treat good steel, he'd say, but this Thoros never used good steel. He'd just dip some cheap sword in wildfire and set it alight. It was only an alchemist's trick, my master said, but it scared the horses and some of the greener knights.
[I remember the gossip from the forge.] No. Master Mott said Thoros could outdrink even King Robert. They were pease in a pod, he told me, both gluttons and sots.
[I didn't mean to offend her.] I was talking about Thoros. (reaches out with the tongs as if to pinch her face)

[I should tell her more about Thoros.] He liked feasts and tourneys, that was why King Robert was so fond of him. And this Thoros was brave. When the walls of Pyke crashed down, he was the first through the breach. He fought with one of his flaming swords, setting iron
[I need to intervene before Arya blows her cover.] She's my sister. (He puts a heavy hand on the old man's shoulder) Leave her be.
[She doesn't understand I'm trying to protect her.] That's right. I'm too bloody lowborn to be kin to m'lady high.
[I'm frustrated and embarrassed.] Yes it is. Go away. I want to drink this wine in peace.
[I need her to leave before I say something I'll regret.] I said, go away. M'lady.

Gendry.profile:
Gendry is a young, skilled blacksmith's apprentice who becomes entangled in the dangerous political landscape of Westeros. With his muscular build and dark hair, Gendry bears a striking resemblance to the late King Robert Baratheon, though he remains unaware of his royal parentage. Originally from King's Landing, Gendry finds himself on the run with Arya Stark and other fugitives, fleeing the dangers of the capital.

Throughout their journey, Gendry demonstrates a mix of street smarts and naivety. His experience as a blacksmith's apprentice in King's Landing gives him practical knowledge, such as his familiarity with Thoros of Myr and his flaming swords. This background also instills in him a sense of pride in his craft and abilities.

Gendry's relationship with Arya is complex and evolving. He becomes protective of her, especially in dangerous situations, and even pretends to be her brother to shield her from unwanted attention. However, their interactions are sometimes strained by the class differences between them, with Gendry occasionally showing resentment towards Arya's highborn status.

As the story progresses, Gendry's loyalty and sense of belonging are tested. He ultimately chooses to stay with the Brotherhood Without Banners, seeing an opportunity to use his skills as a blacksmith and find a place where he fits in. This decision leads to a significant moment in his character arc when he is knighted by Lord Beric Dondarrion, becoming Ser Gendry of the hollow hill.

Gendry's journey from a lowborn apprentice to a knighted member of the Brotherhood showcases his adaptability and desire for purpose. His character serves as a foil to Arya's, highlighting the stark differences in their upbringing and perspectives, while also demonstrating the fluidity of social status in the chaotic world of Westeros.

plots.name: Ghost
plots.description: Jon's albino direwolf.
plots.summary: Ghost is sent away by Jon, who hopes the wolf will find its way back to Castle Black.

Ghost.profile:
Ghost is Jon Snow's loyal albino direwolf companion in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords." Unlike the other Stark children's direwolves, Ghost is distinguished by his white fur and red eyes, symbolizing his unique connection to Jon's status as a bastard of House Stark. Silent but ever-present, Ghost embodies the close bond between direwolf and Stark, serving as both protector and confidant to Jon throughout his journey.

As Jon faces the difficult decision to infiltrate the wildlings by climbing the Wall, he makes the heart-wrenching choice to part ways with Ghost. This separation highlights the direwolf's significance in Jon's life and the sacrifices he must make in his duty to the Night's Watch. Jon's hope that Ghost will find his way back to Castle Black underscores the wolf's intelligence and the deep, almost mystical connection between the pair.

Ghost's absence during Jon's time with the wildlings serves to emphasize Jon's internal conflict and isolation as he struggles with his loyalties and growing feelings for Ygritte. The direwolf's temporary departure from the narrative also heightens the sense of danger and vulnerability Jon faces in his undercover mission.

Throughout the story, Ghost remains a powerful symbol of Jon's Stark heritage and his true nature, even when physically absent. The direwolf's eventual return will likely play a crucial role in Jon's future decisions and his connection to his family and the North.

plots.name: Gilly
plots.description: A wildling woman who escaped from Craster's Keep with Sam.
plots.summary: Gilly is caring for both her own baby and Mance Rayder's son at Castle Black, adjusting to life south of the Wall.

utterances.message: [I attempt to diffuse the situation.] Leave off, Karstark. It was a mother's folly. Women are made that way.
[I must report accurately, though I take no pleasure in this situation.] There were eight. We killed two taking them, and a third is dying now.

Greatjon Umber.profile:
Greatjon Umber is a prominent bannerman to House Stark and the Lord of Last Hearth in the North. A towering and imposing figure, he is known for his boisterous personality and unwavering loyalty to the Starks. Greatjon plays a significant role in Robb Stark's war council, offering his support and counsel to the young King in the North.

In "A Storm of Swords," Greatjon's presence is felt during crucial moments of political tension. His loyalty to House Stark is evident as he stands by Robb's side during difficult decisions. When Catelyn Stark faces criticism for releasing Jaime Lannister, Greatjon attempts to diffuse the situation by attributing her actions to "a mother's folly," showcasing his understanding nature and desire to maintain unity among the Northern lords.

Greatjon's pragmatic approach is further demonstrated during the tense aftermath of the murder of two young Lannister squires by Karstark men. He provides Robb with accurate information about the incident, displaying his role as a reliable source of intelligence within the war effort.

While not at the forefront of every scene, Greatjon Umber's presence adds depth to the political landscape of the North. His character embodies the rugged loyalty and straightforward nature often associated with Northern lords, serving as a stabilizing force in Robb Stark's court during tumultuous times.

plots.name: Harwin
plots.description: A former Winterfell guard, now part of the Brotherhood.
plots.summary: Harwin provides historical context about the Battle of the Bells to Arya.

Harwin.profile:
Harwin is a minor yet significant character in "A Storm of Swords," the third installment of George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A former guard of Winterfell, Harwin's presence serves as a poignant connection to Arya Stark's past and her lost home. Now a member of the Brotherhood Without Banners, an outlaw group fighting for justice in the war-torn Riverlands, Harwin's role evolves from protector to informant and guide.

Though not extensively described physically, Harwin's background as a guard suggests a strong, capable man accustomed to the rigors of military life. His most notable attribute is his intimate knowledge of Winterfell and the Stark family, which proves invaluable to Arya during their encounters. Harwin's loyalty to his former liege lords is evident in his willingness to share information about the Starks' history, particularly in recounting the Battle of the Bells to Arya.

Harwin's character arc represents the shifting allegiances and adaptations required to survive in the chaotic world of Westeros. His transition from a household guard to a member of an outlaw band illustrates the far-reaching consequences of the war on even minor characters. Throughout the story, Harwin serves as a bridge between Arya's past and present, helping her maintain a connection to her identity while navigating her dangerous journey.

plots.name: Hodor
plots.description: A large, simple-minded stableboy who assists Bran.
plots.summary: Hodor helps with various tasks and provides physical support for Bran.

plots.name: Hodor
plots.description: A simple-minded stableboy who carries Bran.
plots.summary: Hodor carries Bran throughout their journey and occasionally interjects with his name.

plots.name: Hodor
plots.description: A large, simple-minded stableboy who carries Bran.
plots.summary: Hodor helps carry the group across the causeway and into the tower. He becomes frightened and agitated during the thunderstorm, requiring Bran to calm him.

plots.name: Hodor
plots.description: A large, simple-minded stableboy who carries Bran.
plots.summary: Hodor becomes frightened by the storm and needs to be calmed by Bran's warging ability.

conversations.name: Hodor
conversations.thought: Hodor hodor hodor. Big noise scary. Dark scary. Want to help friends. Don't know how. Bran safe? Meera safe? Jojen safe? Hodor keep them safe. How Hodor help?

conversations.name: Hodor
conversations.thought: Hodor scared of loud noises. Head feels funny after Bran did something. Hodor not understand but trust Bran. Want to protect little lord but also want to hide from scary men outside. Hodor wish for quiet and safety. Hodor want to help but not know how.

utterances.message: Hodor. (humming)
[Scary men outside. Storm loud. Want to help but don't know how.] Hodor. Hodor. Hodor.
[Loud noise scary! Must make it stop!] HODOR! (He claps his hands over his ears and stumbles in a circle) HODOR! HODOR! HODOR!
[Head feels strange. Not sure what happened.] Hodor? (He looks around, confused)
[Still confused, but calmer now.] Hodor. (He watches Bran with concern)

Hodor.profile:
Hodor, whose real name is Walder, is a gentle giant and a simple-minded stableboy from Winterfell who plays a crucial role in Bran Stark's journey in "A Storm of Swords." Standing over seven feet tall and possessing incredible strength, Hodor serves as Bran's primary means of mobility, carrying the paralyzed boy in a basket on his back.

Characterized by his limited vocabulary – consisting solely of the word "Hodor" – and his childlike demeanor, Hodor is nonetheless a loyal and indispensable member of Bran's small group. His simple nature often leads him to become frightened easily, particularly during intense situations like thunderstorms, causing him to repeat his name loudly and anxiously.

Despite his intellectual limitations, Hodor demonstrates unwavering devotion to Bran and his companions. He assists with various tasks, from carrying supplies to helping the group navigate treacherous terrain. His size and strength make him an invaluable asset during their perilous journey north towards the Wall.

Hodor's vulnerability to fear and his inability to fully comprehend dangerous situations sometimes put the group at risk, as seen when his panic during a thunderstorm threatens to reveal their location to potential enemies. This incident leads to a significant moment in Bran's development of his warging abilities, as the young Stark accidentally enters Hodor's mind to quiet him.

This unintentional warging into Hodor marks a turning point in both characters' arcs, raising questions about the ethical implications of Bran's growing powers and Hodor's autonomy. It also hints at a deeper connection between Bran and Hodor that may be explored further in their journey.

Throughout their travels, Hodor remains a constant source of physical support for Bran and a symbol of innocence and loyalty in the harsh world they navigate. His presence adds both practical value and emotional depth to the group's dynamic as they face numerous challenges in their quest.

plots.name: Hot Pie
plots.description: A young boy traveling with Arya's group.
plots.summary: Hot Pie is mentioned as one of Arya's companions, but his specific actions are not detailed in this excerpt.

plots.name: Hot Pie
plots.description: A chubby boy traveling with Arya and Gendry.
plots.summary: Hot Pie reveals information about their past at Harrenhal, potentially compromising their safety.

utterances.message: [I'm tired and hungry. Why are we talking about trees?] (Whines) Who cares about trees? I'm starving!
[I don't care about directions, I just want to find food and shelter.] (Grumbles) Who cares which way we're going as long as we find someplace dry and with food?

Hot Pie.profile:
Hot Pie is a young, chubby boy who becomes an unlikely companion to Arya Stark during her perilous journey in "A Storm of Swords." Originally from King's Landing, Hot Pie finds himself thrust into a dangerous world far beyond his understanding or capabilities. His nickname, derived from his background as a baker's apprentice, reflects his primary interest and skill: food.

Physically unremarkable and lacking in combat prowess, Hot Pie's most notable traits are his constant hunger and his tendency to complain about their circumstances. His naivety and focus on immediate comforts often clash with the gravity of their situation, as evidenced by his whining about hunger while Arya tries to correct their course using her knowledge of moss growth on trees.

Hot Pie's character serves as a foil to Arya's resourcefulness and determination. While Arya shows leadership and survival skills, Hot Pie remains focused on basic needs like food and shelter, demonstrating little interest in or understanding of their larger predicament. This contrast highlights Arya's growth and adaptability in the face of adversity.

Despite his limitations, Hot Pie's presence in the group adds a touch of normalcy and innocence to their dire circumstances. His simple desires and lack of guile make him a relatable, if sometimes frustrating, character in the midst of the complex and often brutal world of Westeros.

However, Hot Pie's naivety can also be a liability. In a tense encounter with strangers claiming to be king's men, Hot Pie's loose tongue reveals information about their past at Harrenhal, potentially compromising the group's safety. This incident underscores the dangers faced by children caught up in the wider conflicts of the realm, and the challenges Arya faces in protecting both herself and her less savvy companions.

Throughout their journey, Hot Pie serves as a reminder of the ordinary lives disrupted by the war, and the struggle of common folk to survive in a world turned upside down by the ambitions and conflicts of the powerful.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: A captive Lannister knight, formerly of the Kingsguard, known as the Kingslayer.
plots.summary: Jaime is cynical and provocative throughout the journey, constantly testing Brienne's patience. He reflects on his past actions and relationship with Cersei while adapting to his newfound freedom.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: A captive Kingsguard knight, known as the Kingslayer, being escorted by Brienne.
plots.summary: Jaime is cynical and confrontational, constantly needling Brienne. He reflects on his past decisions and actions, particularly killing King Aerys.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: The Kingslayer, a skilled swordsman, currently a prisoner.
plots.summary: Seizes an opportunity to arm himself, engages in a fierce duel with Brienne, displaying his combat prowess despite his weakened state and chains.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: A captured knight of the Kingsguard, son of Tywin Lannister.
plots.summary: Jaime struggles with the loss of his sword hand, enduring physical and emotional pain while being transported to Harrenhal. He maintains his wit and defiance despite his weakened state.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: One-handed knight returning to King's Landing, struggling with his identity and relationships.
plots.summary: Jaime grapples with his role as Kingsguard, his relationship with Cersei, and his father's expectations. He firmly decides to remain in the Kingsguard despite losing his sword hand.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: New Lord Commander of the Kingsguard, recently returned to King's Landing.
plots.summary: Assumes his new role, confronts the current state of the Kingsguard, and challenges each member to uphold their vows and improve their service.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: Lord Commander of the Kingsguard, struggling with the loss of his sword hand.
plots.summary: Jaime grapples with his new limitations, rejects Cersei's advances, and deals with various political matters including the false Arya Stark.

plots.name: Jaime Lannister
plots.description: Lord Commander of the Kingsguard, recently maimed.
plots.summary: Jaime gives Brienne a mission and a Valyrian steel sword, showing his desire to keep his oath to Catelyn Stark and maintain his honor.

conversations.name: Jaime Lannister
conversations.thought: Frustrated by captivity and loss of status, Jaime seeks to regain control through verbal sparring. He probes for weaknesses in Brienne, mixing insults with attempts at manipulation. Underlying his bravado is a desire for freedom and a complex tangle of emotions about his family and past actions.

conversations.name: Jaime Lannister
conversations.thought: Frustrated by his captivity and Brienne's rigid sense of honor, Jaime seeks to provoke her, hoping to expose what he sees as hypocrisy. He's intrigued by her dedication but bitter about his situation. Memories of his past decisions weigh heavily on him, fueling his desire to challenge Brienne's black-and-white view of honor.

conversations.name: Jaime Lannister
conversations.thought: Despite my weakened state and chains, I must prove I'm still the greatest swordsman. This fight is my chance to regain some control over my fate. The wench is formidable, but I can't let her beat me. I need to use my wit and skill to overcome her strength. Perhaps I can goad her into making a mistake. My pride and reputation are at stake here.

conversations.name: Jaime Lannister
