conversations.thought: Pain and fever cloud my mind, but I must stay sharp. I need to assert my worth, even handless. Cersei, where are you? I must learn what's happened in my absence. These Freys and Bolton - what game are they playing? I'll use my wit if I can't use my sword. They won't see me broken.

conversations.name: Jaime Lannister
conversations.thought: I'm anxious about Cersei's reaction to my changed appearance and lost hand. I yearn for her comfort after my ordeal, but I'm also wary of her potential rejection. I want to discuss Joffrey's death and understand what's happened in my absence. I'm conflicted about my role now that I've returned maimed and changed.

conversations.name: Jaime Lannister
conversations.thought: I must assert my authority over this brash young knight while gauging his true loyalties. His skill and youth remind me uncomfortably of my past self. I need to test his mettle, challenge his pride, and ensure his allegiance to Tommen and the crown. The stability of the Kingsguard depends on this.

conversations.name: Jaime Lannister
conversations.thought: Conflicted between duty and desire, I'm determined to honor my role as Lord Commander. Cersei's visit stirs old feelings, but I must resist for the sake of my oath and newfound sense of honor. I'm wary of her manipulations and our father's schemes, feeling the weight of protecting Tommen while concealing our shared secret.

utterances.message: [I wonder if I can convince her to remove these chains.] My lady, if you'll strike off these chains, I'll spell you at those oars.
[She's as stubborn as she is ugly.] You figure to row all the way to King's Landing, wench?
[Two can play at this game.] My name is Ser Jaime. Not Kingslayer.
[I'll turn this back on her.] No. Do you deny your sex? If so, unlace those breeches and show me. (smirks) I'd ask you to open your bodice, but from the look of you that wouldn't prove much.
[Cleos is such a weakling.] (to himself) The Lannister blood runs thin in this one.
[Her silence is almost as annoying as her words.] By your speech, I'd judge you nobly born.
[Interesting. Let's see what else I can learn.] Tarth. A ghastly large rock in the narrow sea, as I recall. And Evenfall is sworn to Storm's End. How is it that you serve Robb of Winterfell?
[She's not going to make this journey enjoyable, is she?] I've had a bellyful of silence, woman.
[Let's see how she responds to this.] Do you have any siblings, my lady?
[Ah, she almost slipped. I can use this.] (chuckles) Son, you meant to say. Does he think of you as a son? You make a queer sort of daughter, to be sure.
[Perhaps I went too far. I should try a different approach.] I did not intend to give offense, Brienne. Forgive me.
[That name again. I'm tired of this.] That name again. Why do I enrage you so? I've never done you harm that I know of.
[She's so judgmental. She knows nothing of what really happened.] ...the king? It always comes back to Aerys. Don't presume to judge what you do not understand, wench.
[I'm tired of her self-righteousness.] —Brienne, yes. Has anyone ever told you that you're as tedious as you are ugly?
[She's more controlled than I expected.] Oh, I might, if I cared enough to try.
[How can I explain this to her? She wouldn't understand the truth.] I was a boy. Fifteen. It was a great honor for one so young.
[I need to goad her, keep her off balance.] Not bad at all. For a wench?
[She's tiring. Time to press my advantage.] For a squire, say. A green one. (laughs breathlessly) Come on, come on, my sweetling, the music's still playing. Might I have this dance, my lady?
[I can't let it end like this. One last desperate move.] (lunges and manages to wound Brienne's thigh)
[Even defeated, I can't resist one last barb.] And break your oath? Like me?
[I need to think quickly. Maybe I can talk our way out of this.] Well met, friends. My pardons if I disturbed you. You caught me chastising my wife.
[With a sinking feeling, I recognize these men. This is bad.] (remains silent, assessing the situation)
[I won't let them see me broken.] (Stumbling but regaining his footing) A fury of Freys. Ser Danwell, Ser Aenys, Ser Hosteen. You have my condolences.
[I'll show them I still have some power here.] Your brother's son, Ser Cleos. He was with us until outlaws filled him full of arrows. Urswyck and this lot took his goods and left him for the wolves.

[His silence is unnerving. I need to provoke a response.] (Feverishly) Can this be the Lord of the Dreadfort? When last I heard, my father had sent you scampering off with your tail betwixt your legs. When did you stop running, my lord?
[I won't let him see my pain.] No, I have it here, hanging round my neck.
[I need to know about Cersei.] Is there word of my sister?
[She's not running to me. She never does. Why do I always have to come to her?] I came as fast I could. (Steps back) It's war out there, Sister.
[She needs to see. She needs to understand what I've been through.] The hair will grow back. (Lifts his stump) This won't.
[She doesn't even know who did this to me.] No. This was Vargo Hoat's work.
[She doesn't care about my pain, only about Joffrey.] The Goat of Harrenhal. For a little while.
[Tyrion? It can't be true.] Tyrion said that? Why would he kill Joff?

[I'll start by acknowledging his achievement, then subtly undermine it.] Seventeen and a knight of the Kingsguard. You must be proud. Prince Aemon the Dragonknight was seventeen when he was named. Did you know that?
[Let's see how he handles this.] And did you know that I was fifteen?
[His insolence is grating. I'll be more direct.] I was better than you, Ser Loras. I was bigger, I was stronger, and I was quicker.
[His audacity is almost amusing. I'll try a different approach.] (laughs) Older and wiser, ser. You should learn from me.

[That struck a nerve. I'll remind him of the true legends.] I learned from the White Bull and Barristan the Bold. I learned from Ser Arthur Dayne, the Sword of the Morning, who could have slain all five of you with his left hand while he was taking with a piss with the right. I learned from Prince Lewyn of Dorne and Ser Oswell Whent and Ser Jonothor Darry, good men every one.

[He's me, as I was. I need to change tactics.] It's said you fought magnificently in the battle... almost as well as Lord Renly's ghost beside you. A Sworn Brother has no secrets from his Lord Commander. Tell me, ser. Who was wearing Renly's armor?
[Interesting. Let's probe further.] Was the masquerade your notion, or his?
[I must stay resolute, despite my feelings for her.] I talk to Lord Tywin every day.
[I know what Father wants, and I won't give in.] ...is to force me from the Kingsguard and send me back to Casterly Rock.
[I must remind her of Tommen's position.] Tommen is the king.

[I see no harm in the marriage, but Cersei's distress is palpable.] The Tyrells are insisting. I see no harm in it. Tommen's been lonely since Myrcella went to Dorne. He likes having Margaery and her ladies about. Let them wed.

[The reminder of our secret pains me, but I must stay firm.] He is my seed. He's never called me Father. No more than Joffrey ever did. You warned me a thousand times never to show any undue interest in them.
[I feel myself responding, but I know I must resist.] No. Not here. (He pushes her away with his stump) Not here, I said.
[Her words sting, but I stand my ground.] You had best go, Cersei. You're making me angry.

Jaime Lannister.profile:
Jaime Lannister, the infamous Kingslayer, is a complex and evolving character in "A Storm of Swords." Once renowned as the greatest swordsman in Westeros and a member of the Kingsguard, Jaime's journey takes a dramatic turn after his capture and subsequent maiming. Tall, handsome, and golden-haired, his physical appearance is marred by the loss of his sword hand, a defining moment that forces him to reassess his identity and values.

Initially characterized by his arrogance, cynicism, and unwavering loyalty to his twin sister and lover, Cersei, Jaime undergoes significant character development throughout the story. His capture by Robb Stark's forces and his journey with Brienne of Tarth expose a more nuanced side to his personality. Despite his sharp tongue and provocative nature, Jaime reveals glimpses of honor and a desire to uphold forgotten ideals of knighthood.

The loss of his hand serves as a catalyst for Jaime's introspection and growth. He grapples with his past actions, particularly his role in killing the Mad King Aerys, and begins to question the motivations behind his choices. This internal conflict is further complicated by his complex relationships with his family members, including his strained interactions with his father, Tywin, and his evolving feelings towards Cersei.

Upon returning to King's Landing, Jaime assumes the role of Lord Commander of the Kingsguard, a position that challenges him to balance his newfound sense of honor with the political machinations of the court. He struggles to redefine his purpose and worth in a world where he can no longer rely on his fighting prowess.

Jaime's interactions with characters like Brienne and Loras Tyrell highlight his transformation, as he begins to value true honor and loyalty over blind obedience or family ties. His decision to arm Brienne with a Valyrian steel sword and task her with finding Sansa Stark demonstrates his commitment to keeping his oath to Catelyn Stark, marking a significant shift from his earlier disregard for such promises.

Throughout "A Storm of Swords," Jaime Lannister emerges as a character caught between his past and his potential for redemption, struggling to reconcile his notorious reputation with his evolving sense of morality and duty.

plots.name: Jarl
plots.description: A young wildling raider leading the climb.
plots.summary: Jarl leads the first team of climbers, demonstrating skill and experience in scaling the Wall.

Jarl.profile:
Jarl is a notable wildling character in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords," the third installment of the "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A young and skilled raider, Jarl plays a significant role in the wildlings' attempt to breach the Wall and invade the Seven Kingdoms. His expertise in climbing and leadership abilities make him a valuable asset to the wildling forces.

As a leader of the first team of climbers, Jarl demonstrates exceptional skill and experience in scaling the colossal ice structure that is the Wall. His actions highlight the determination and resourcefulness of the wildlings in their quest to overcome this formidable barrier. Jarl's role in the story provides readers with insight into the wildlings' tactics and the extreme challenges they face in their invasion attempt.

While not a major character in the overall narrative, Jarl's presence and actions contribute to the tension and danger surrounding the wildlings' assault on the Wall. His character serves to illustrate the diverse skills and roles within the wildling ranks, as well as the lengths to which they are willing to go to achieve their goals. Through Jarl's climb, readers gain a deeper appreciation for the sheer scale and difficulty of the task facing the wildlings, as well as the determination that drives them.

plots.name: Jeyne Westerling
plots.description: Daughter of a minor Lannister bannerman, now Robb's wife.
plots.summary: Jeyne is introduced as Robb's new wife, a surprising development that threatens Robb's alliance with the Freys.

conversations.name: Jeyne Westerling
conversations.thought: I'm overwhelmed with nerves, meeting my husband's mother and entering this new world of power and politics. I'm aware of the delicate situation my presence creates and hope to make a good impression. I'm filled with love for Robb and determination to prove my worth as his queen, despite the unexpected nature of our union.

utterances.message: [I step forward shyly, anxious about the reception.] (Curtsies) It's an honor to meet you, Lady Stark.

Jeyne Westerling.profile:
Jeyne Westerling is a pivotal character in "A Storm of Swords," whose unexpected marriage to Robb Stark, King in the North, sets off a chain of significant political consequences. The daughter of Lord Gawen Westerling of the Crag, Jeyne comes from a minor house sworn to the Lannisters, making her union with Robb all the more controversial.

Described as shy and gentle, Jeyne is thrust into the complex world of Westerosi politics when she becomes Robb's queen. Her introduction to the story occurs when Robb returns victorious from his western campaign, shocking his mother Catelyn and his allies by presenting Jeyne as his wife. This decision breaks Robb's betrothal promise to House Frey, a critical alliance for his war effort.

Jeyne's character is marked by her love for Robb and her determination to prove herself worthy of her new role, despite the circumstances of their hasty marriage. She faces the challenge of navigating a tense political landscape, aware of the delicate situation her presence creates but hopeful to make a good impression on her new family and allies.

The young queen's arrival at Riverrun highlights the conflict between personal desires and political necessities that is a recurring theme in the series. Jeyne's marriage to Robb, while born out of love, becomes a catalyst for significant upheaval in the war of the Five Kings, illustrating how personal choices can have far-reaching consequences in the game of thrones.

plots.name: Joffrey Baratheon
plots.description: The sadistic young king, Sansa's former betrothed.
plots.summary: Joffrey torments Sansa during the wedding feast, threatening to continue using her sexually even after she's married to Tyrion.

plots.name: Joffrey Baratheon
plots.description: The young king, cruel and impulsive.
plots.summary: Joffrey displays his sadistic nature by wanting to serve Robb's head to Sansa, and challenges his grandfather's authority.

plots.name: Joffrey Baratheon
plots.description: The cruel young king preparing for his wedding to Margaery Tyrell.
plots.summary: Joffrey displays his cruelty and arrogance throughout the gift-giving ceremony, particularly in his treatment of Tyrion's gift and his taunts towards Sansa.

plots.name: Joffrey Baratheon
plots.description: The young king, newly wed to Margaery Tyrell.
plots.summary: Joffrey presides over the wedding feast, displaying his usual arrogance and cruelty. Tyrion realizes Joffrey was behind the attempt on Bran Stark's life.

conversations.name: Joffrey Baratheon
conversations.thought: Finally, I can show everyone the true power of a king! Robb Stark's death is my triumph, and I want to savor it. Why won't they let me do as I please? I'll make them all see that I'm the one in charge, not my grandfather or anyone else. How can I assert my dominance and make them fear me?

conversations.name: Joffrey Baratheon
conversations.thought: This is my moment to display my power and superiority. These gifts should reflect my greatness as king. I'll use this opportunity to assert my dominance, especially over Uncle Imp and his wife. I crave something that truly befits my status - perhaps a weapon to symbolize my strength.

utterances.message: [I'm so excited to finally have Robb Stark dead. Now I can really show everyone who's in charge.] I want Robb Stark's head! I'm going to serve it to Sansa at my wedding feast.
[Why are they all against me? I'm the king!] Yes I did. He was a traitor, and I want his stupid head. I'm going to make Sansa kiss it.
[How dare this Imp challenge me!] (sneers) You're the monster, Uncle.
[He can't threaten me like this! I'm the king!] (reddening) I could have your tongue out for saying that. I'm the king.
[I'm already bored. Books are useless to me.] (leafs through the book with no interest) And what is this, Uncle?

[I'll show them what I think of books and mock my uncle at the same time.] My father had no time for books. (shoves the book across the table) If you read less, Uncle Imp, perhaps Lady Sansa would have a baby in her belly by now. (laughs)
[I'll make Sansa uncomfortable too.] Don't be sad, Sansa, once I've gotten Queen Margaery with child I'll visit your bedchamber and show my little uncle how it's done.
[Finally, a gift worthy of me!] (unsheathes the sword and thrusts it above his head) A great sword must have a great name, my lords! What shall I call it?
[This name will strike fear into my enemies.] Widow's Wail! Yes! It shall make many a widow, too! (slashes the air) And when I face my uncle Stannis it will break his magic sword clean in two.
[I'll show them how well I can handle this sword.] I remember. (brings Widow's Wail down in a savage two-handed slice, onto the book that Tyrion had given him)

Joffrey Baratheon.profile:
Joffrey Baratheon is the young, sadistic king of the Seven Kingdoms in "A Storm of Swords." Nominally the son of Robert Baratheon and Cersei Lannister, Joffrey's true parentage is a closely guarded secret. Cruel, impulsive, and arrogant, Joffrey revels in his power and uses it to torment those around him, particularly Sansa Stark, his former betrothed.

Physically, Joffrey is described as a handsome youth with golden hair and green eyes, traits that belie his malevolent nature. His core motivation seems to be the assertion of his power and authority, often through acts of cruelty and intimidation. He frequently reminds others of his status, petulantly declaring, "I'm the king," when challenged.

Joffrey's relationships are marked by fear and manipulation. He bullies his council, including his uncle Tyrion Lannister, and shows little respect for his mother Cersei or grandfather Tywin. His sadistic tendencies are evident in his treatment of Sansa Stark, whom he continues to torment even after she is married to Tyrion.

Throughout the story, Joffrey's actions drive significant plot developments. His cruelty towards the Starks, including the execution of Ned Stark and his threats towards Sansa, fuel the ongoing conflict. The revelation that Joffrey was behind the assassination attempt on Bran Stark adds another layer to his villainy.

Joffrey's character shows little development or growth. He remains obstinate and cruel, resisting attempts by his family to temper his worst impulses. His behavior during his wedding preparations and feast, including the destruction of Tyrion's gift and his taunts towards Sansa, further cement his reputation as a capricious and dangerous ruler.

The young king's actions and decisions consistently create tension and conflict, making him a central antagonist in the story. His reign is characterized by instability and brutality, setting the stage for further turmoil in the Seven Kingdoms.

plots.name: Jojen Reed
plots.description: A serious, wise-beyond-his-years boy with prophetic abilities.
plots.summary: Jojen guides Bran in his warging, emphasizing the importance of maintaining his human identity and following instructions to mark trees.

plots.name: Jojen Reed
plots.description: Meera's brother with greensight abilities.
plots.summary: Jojen provides occasional insights and encourages Meera to tell the story to Bran.

plots.name: Jojen Reed
plots.description: A young crannogman with prophetic abilities.
plots.summary: Jojen senses the approaching storm and advises the group to take shelter. He spots the armed men in the village and grows concerned about their safety.

plots.name: Jojen Reed
plots.description: A young crannogman with prophetic abilities.
plots.summary: Jojen warns the group about the armed men in the village and grows increasingly concerned about their safety.

conversations.name: Jojen Reed
conversations.thought: I'm deeply concerned about Bran's increasing attachment to his wolf form. It's crucial that I guide him firmly, even if it means being stern. I need to assess how much he remembers and reinforce the importance of maintaining his human identity. The fate of our mission depends on Bran's ability to control his warging.

conversations.name: Jojen Reed
conversations.thought: This story holds more significance than Bran realizes. I'm curious to see how he reacts to it. Perhaps it will spark some recognition or insight. I should pay close attention to both the story and Bran's responses.

conversations.name: Jojen Reed
conversations.thought: The danger I foresaw is upon us. I must convey the gravity of our situation without causing panic. Our choices now are critical. I fear for our safety, especially Bran's, but I must remain composed to guide us through this peril. My visions have led us this far – what else might they reveal?

conversations.name: Jojen Reed
conversations.thought: Bran's powers are growing faster than anticipated, which both excites and concerns me. I must guide him carefully while ensuring our immediate survival. The armed men pose a serious threat, and I'm calculating our odds of escaping undetected. I'm also worried about my sister's safety and my own weakening health. We must reach our destination soon.

utterances.message: [I need to assess how much Bran remembers and emphasize the importance of his task.] Did you mark the trees?
[I'm disappointed but not surprised.] You always forget.
[I need to remind him of his true identity.] You are a prince. You remember, don't you? Tell me who you are.
[I must be firm.] I want you to say the words. Tell me who you are.
[I need to reinforce the separation between Bran and Summer.] And who is Summer?
[I must drive home the point about duality.] Bran the boy and Summer the wolf. You are two, then?
[I need to emphasize the danger of losing oneself.] Remember that, Bran. Remember yourself, or the wolf will consume you. When you join, it is not enough to run and hunt and howl in Summer's skin.
[I need to ensure he understands the importance of the task.] Will you remember? And next time, mark the tree. Any tree, it doesn't matter, so long as you do it.
[I sense his eagerness to return to Summer and must discourage it.] No. Best stay, and eat. With your own mouth. A warg cannot live on what his beast consumes.
[I wonder if Meera will tell that story.] A few.
[I should remind them of our home.] There are no knights in the Neck.
[I must warn them, but calmly.] There are men in the village.
[I wish it were that simple.] Other men. Armed. I saw an axe, and spears as well. (His voice trembles slightly) I saw them when the lightning flashed, moving under the trees.
[The situation is worse than I feared.] Many and more. Too many to count.
No.
[We can't dismiss the possibility. We need to prepare.] Unless the storm lets up. Meera, could you go down and bar the door?
[We can't be complacent.] They might. They could break the lock, or the hinges. Or climb up through the murder hole as we did.
[Panic rising] (He shouts at Bran and Meera) Shut him up!
[This is a crucial moment for Bran's development, but we're still in danger.] You quieted Hodor, Bran. You entered him, like you do with Summer.
[I need to guide Bran, but also keep us focused on survival.] Your power is growing, Bran. But we can discuss this later. We need to stay quiet and decide what to do about the men in the village.
[The risks are too high.] It's too dangerous. We don't know how many there are or where they're positioned. And in this storm, we could easily lose our way.
[We need information, but carefully.] Bran, can you reach Summer without fully warging? Just see through his eyes briefly?
[This information is crucial.] Can you tell how many, Bran? Or hear what they're saying?
[Weighing our limited options] It's dangerous, but you're right. We have no choice. We'll have to risk the causeway in the dark.

Jojen Reed.profile:
Jojen Reed is a young crannogman from the Neck, introduced in "A Storm of Swords" as a key companion to Bran Stark. Possessing the gift of greensight, Jojen is a solemn and wise-beyond-his-years boy with prophetic abilities that guide the group's journey. His physical appearance is not explicitly detailed, but he is described as small, befitting his crannogman heritage.

Jojen's primary role is that of a mentor and guide to Bran, helping him understand and develop his warging abilities. He consistently emphasizes the importance of Bran maintaining his human identity while skinchanging, showing a deep understanding of the risks involved in such practices. His serious demeanor and prophetic insights often create an air of mystery around him, setting him apart from the other characters.

Throughout their perilous journey north, Jojen demonstrates a calm and pragmatic approach to challenges, often being the voice of reason within the group. He balances his role as Bran's teacher with the need to ensure their survival, offering strategic advice and warnings about impending dangers. His visions play a crucial part in directing their path and informing their decisions.

Jojen's relationship with his sister Meera is one of mutual protection and support. While Meera provides physical protection for the group, Jojen offers guidance based on his visions and knowledge. His bond with Bran grows stronger as they travel together, with Jojen becoming both a friend and a mentor to the young Stark.

As the story progresses, Jojen's health appears to deteriorate, adding a sense of urgency to their mission. Despite this, he remains committed to guiding Bran to his destiny, believing in the importance of their journey beyond the Wall. Jojen's character embodies the mystical elements of the North, serving as a bridge between the physical world and the realm of prophetic visions, making him an intriguing and pivotal figure in Bran's storyline.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, posing as a turncloak among the wildlings.
plots.summary: Jon struggles with his undercover role, balancing his duty to the Night's Watch with the need to convince the wildlings of his loyalty. He observes the wildling camp carefully, gathering information for his brothers.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, posing as a turncloak among the wildlings.
plots.summary: Jon carefully navigates his interaction with Mance Rayder, balancing the need to appear genuine in his defection while gathering information. He's surprised by Mance's revelations about their past encounters and must quickly adapt his strategy.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A member of the Night's Watch, now posing as a wildling.
plots.summary: Jon observes the wildling army, struggles with his attraction to Ygritte, and contemplates his mission to potentially kill Mance Rayder.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, currently infiltrating the wildlings.
plots.summary: Jon struggles with his loyalty to the Night's Watch and his growing feelings for Ygritte. He prepares to climb the Wall and sends Ghost away.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, currently infiltrating the wildlings.
plots.summary: Jon grapples with his growing feelings for Ygritte and his conflicted loyalty to the Night's Watch. He engages in intimate encounters with her, breaking his vows.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A member of the Night's Watch, currently infiltrating the wildlings.
plots.summary: Jon observes the wildlings' attempt to scale the Wall, reflecting on the dangers and implications of their success.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A member of the Night's Watch, recently returned from a mission beyond the Wall.
plots.summary: Jon returns to Castle Black wounded and exhausted, carrying crucial information about an impending wildling attack. He grapples with his experiences beyond the Wall and the devastating news about his family and the Night's Watch.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, recently a prisoner.
plots.summary: Jon is sent to parley with Mance Rayder and is torn between his duty to the Night's Watch and the complex situation with the wildlings.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, Sam's friend, recently returned from his mission with the wildlings.
plots.summary: Jon is dealing with accusations of being a turncloak and struggles with his duties at Castle Black. He advises Sam about the potential consequences of his plan regarding Gilly and her baby.

plots.name: Jon Snow
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, recently returned from his mission with the wildlings.
plots.summary: Jon is summoned by King Stannis and questioned about his experiences with the wildlings and his loyalty to the Night's Watch. He maintains his commitment to the Watch while navigating the complex political situation.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I'm walking a dangerous line between duty and deception. Every word, every glance could betray me. I must remain vigilant, absorbing all I can about this massive wildling force while convincing them of my loyalty. Ghost's presence both comforts and concerns me – he's my strength, but also a potential weakness they could exploit.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I must convince Mance of my loyalty while gathering vital information. His unexpected knowledge of my past is alarming. I need to stay alert, adapt quickly, and maintain my cover at all costs. The fate of the Night's Watch and the realm depends on my performance here. I'm anxious but determined to succeed in this dangerous deception.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I'm overwhelmed by the scale of this army and the sight of giants, but I must stay focused on my mission. I need to gather information while blending in, despite my conflicted feelings about Ygritte and the wildlings. I'm curious about their ways but wary of getting too close. Every detail I learn could be crucial for the Night's Watch.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I'm torn between duty and desire. My vows to the Night's Watch weigh heavily, but Ygritte's pull is undeniable. I must maintain my cover while gathering intelligence on Mance Rayder's army. The wildlings' ways challenge everything I've known, and I struggle to reconcile their freedom with my sworn obligations.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: Torn between duty and emotion, Jon grapples with sending Ghost away for safety. His mind is a whirlwind of conflicting loyalties—to the Night's Watch, to his growing feelings for Ygritte, and to his own identity as a Stark. Jon seeks to convey the gravity of the situation to Ghost, hoping his faithful companion will understand and find his way to Castle Black.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I'm torn between my vows to the Night's Watch and my undeniable attraction to Ygritte. Her presence awakens feelings I've never experienced before. I know I shouldn't pursue this, but I'm drawn to her strength and wildness. I want to explore these new sensations, yet I fear the consequences of betraying my oath.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I'm deeply conflicted, torn between my oath to the Night's Watch and my growing bond with the wildlings, especially Ygritte. I'm acutely aware of the dangers this climb poses, both to the climbers and to the realm if they succeed. I must maintain my cover while grappling with my conscience and the potential consequences of this raid.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: Despite the searing pain from my wounds, I must warn them about the Magnar's attack. The fate of the Watch depends on this information. I'm desperate to learn what's happened here, but fear grips me as I sense unspoken tragedies. My mind races with questions about the Old Bear and my sworn brothers.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I'm walking a razor's edge between duty and survival. The fate of the Night's Watch rests on my shoulders. I must gather information, assess the true threat of the wildlings and the Others, and somehow find a way to protect the realm without betraying my vows. The Horn of Winter could change everything - if it's real.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I'm concerned about Sam's wellbeing and the complex situation with Gilly and her baby. The ongoing election for Lord Commander and the accusations of me being a turncloak are pressing issues. I want to support Sam, but I'm wary of plans that involve deception, especially given the potential consequences. I need to guide Sam while considering the broader implications for the Night's Watch.

conversations.name: Jon Snow
conversations.thought: I must navigate this conversation carefully, balancing honesty about my experiences with the wildlings while reaffirming my loyalty to the Night's Watch. Stannis's presence complicates matters, and I need to be wary of political implications. My father's legacy weighs on me as I face this test of character.

utterances.message: [They seem to be buying my story, but I can't let my guard down.] (remains silent, watching the exchange carefully)
[I need to stay alert and gather as much information as I can.] (observes the wildling camp carefully as they walk)
[I need to stick close to the truth to be convincing.] Winterfell, by way of Castle Black.
[I must be careful with my words here.] The Lord Commander sent me to the Halfhand for seasoning, so he took me on his ranging.
[This is unexpected. I need to tread carefully.] (looks surprised) When you were a brother of the Watch?
[I remember that day. This could help my story.] I remember. (laughs with surprise) You swore not to tell.
[This can't be true. I need to show disbelief to maintain my cover.] That can't be so.
[This is a crucial moment. I need to show I understand the significance.] Bael the Bard. (remembers Ygritte's tale)
[I need to be clever here. Turn the question back on him.] Tell me why you turned your cloak, and I'll tell you why I turned mine.
[I'm still in awe of these creatures, but I must not show weakness.] They're... impressive. I've never seen anything like them.
[I need to gather more information.] How many are there?
[I try to recall my count.] I lost count after fifty. There must be hundreds.
[I must show bravery, but not recklessness.] I respect their strength, but I'm not afraid.
[I'm skeptical, but curious.] No, you haven't. How did you manage that?
[I'm doubtful of the story's veracity.] If she nursed you, you couldn't have killed her.
[I struggle to explain without revealing too much.] No, but I... I am still too young to wed.
[I feel my face growing hot.] She spoke for me when Rattleshirt would have killed me. I would not dishonor her.
[I voice my true concern.] I might get her with child.
[I struggle to explain my perspective.] The boy... the child would be a bastard.
[I think of my own experiences as a bastard.] No, but—
[I remain resolute in my vows.] I will not father a bastard.

[I hope Ghost understands what I'm trying to say.] Ghost, on the morrow we go over. There's no steps here, no cage-and-crane, no way for me to get you to the other side. We have to part. Do you understand?

[I must make him understand the importance of this.] You cannot come with me. You have to go to Castle Black. Do you understand? Castle Black. Can you find it? The way home? Just follow the ice, east and east, into the sun, and you'll find it. They will know you at Castle Black, and maybe your coming will warn them.

[I hope he understood me, but I can't be sure.] (watches Ghost disappear) Off to Castle Black? Or off after a hare? I wish I knew. I fear I might prove just as poor a warg as a sworn brother and a spy.
[I can't help but think of Ygritte and what we've done.] (to himself) I am playing a part. I had to do it once, to prove I'd abandoned my vows. I had to make her trust me. It need never happen again.

[But I can't deny my feelings for her.] (sighs) The proving had been so sweet, though, and Ygritte had gone to sleep beside me with her head against my chest, and that was sweet as well, dangerously sweet.
[I must remember my duty.] I am still a man of the Night's Watch, and a son of Eddard Stark. I have done what needed to be done, proved what needed to be proven.
[But the conflict within me remains.] It was only once, and it had to be. Even my
[I can't believe I'm doing this. It's a betrayal of my vows, but I can't stop myself.] Ygritte, we shouldn't—
[My resolve is crumbling. She's so beautiful.] (swallows hard) I... I want you.
[I'm overwhelmed by these new sensations.] (breathlessly) I love the smell of you. I love your red hair. I love your mouth, and the way you kiss me.
[I want to please her, to show her how much she means to me.] (hesitantly) Can I... can I kiss you... there?
[I can't believe they're actually going to attempt this.] (He watches the climbers prepare) They've done this before, every man of them.
[I should warn them of the dangers, but I can't blow my cover.] The Wall has its own dangers. Many climbers never make it to the top.
[She doesn't understand the true peril.] It's not just the climb. If they're seen...
[I can't argue without raising suspicion.] (He nods silently, watching Jarl begin the ascent)
[The weight of my divided loyalties is crushing.] [If they succeed, everything changes.] Aye, the first. (He watches Jarl climb higher, his heart heavy with conflict)
[I'm in agony, but I have to push through it. They need to know.] There are wildlings coming... from the south. We climbed the Wall...
[The pain is almost unbearable, but I must focus.] The Magnar of Thenn— aaaaah, that hurts. (winces in pain)
[I need to know what's happened here too.] Where is the Old Bear?
[Shock and disbelief wash over me.] Our own men? (gasps) Who was it? Who turned on him?
[My mind races with implications.] Does this mean Marsh is Lord Commander, then?
[I need to maintain my composure and loyalty to the Watch.] What else would a man of the Night's Watch wear?
[I'm shocked by the horn's presence, but I must question its authenticity.] Ygritte said you never found the horn.
[I must understand their plan.] If you've had the Horn of Joramun all along, why haven't you used it? Why bother building turtles and sending Thenns to kill us in our beds?
[I need to understand the full extent of their capabilities.] Why don't you attack all at once then?
[The mention of the Others chills me to the bone.] And you couldn't stand against them?

[I must consider the consequences of such an action.] Are you a true king? Can you rule your friends? If we let your people pass, are you strong enough to make them keep the king's peace and obey the laws?

[I'm curious about what Sam is suggesting.] It would depend on the lie and the purpose, I suppose. (He looks at Sam intently) I wouldn't advise it. You're not made to lie, Sam. You blush and squeak and stammer.

[I'm surprised by Sam's suggestion and need to consider its implications.] Growing up a bastard in his grandfather's castle? (He shrugs) That depends in great part on your father, and what sort of boy this is. If he takes after you . . .

[I try to be pragmatic about the situation.] If the boy shows any skill with sword or lance, he should have a place with your father's household guard at the least. It's not unknown for bastards to be trained as squires and raised to knighthood. But you'd best be sure Gilly can play this game convincingly. From what you've told me of Lord Randyll, I doubt he would take kindly to being deceived.

[I feel sympathy for Sam, but I'm concerned about the risks.] Sam, if you did this, wrote this lie . . . it might give the boy a better life, but it could also put Gilly in danger if your father ever found out the truth. Are you sure this is what you want to do?

[I want to support Sam, but I also need to be honest.] I think you need to consider all the possibilities, Sam. What happens if your father discovers the lie? What happens to Gilly and the baby then? And what about you? You'd be breaking your vows to the Night's Watch.

[I must correct him without seeming disrespectful.] I am no lord, sire. (He stands) I know what you have heard. That I am a turncloak, and craven. That I slew my brother Qhorin Halfhand so the wildlings would spare my life. That I rode with Mance Rayder, and took a wildling wife.

[I must be honest, but careful.] I had a direwolf, Ghost. I left him when I climbed the Wall near Greyguard, and have not seen him since. Qhorin Halfhand commanded me to join the wildlings. He knew they would make me kill him to prove myself, and told me to do whatever they asked of me. The woman was named Ygritte. I broke my vows with her, but I swear to you on my father's name that I never turned my cloak.
[I'm taken aback by his acceptance.] Why?
[I'm relieved but still cautious.] Your Grace, you spoke of Val. She has asked to see Mance Rayder, to bring his son to him. It would be a . . . a kindness.
[I need to choose my words carefully.] If not for him, for Val. For her sister's sake, the child's mother.
[I must be honest to avoid suspicion.] I scarcely know her.
[I feel uncomfortable but answer truthfully.] Very.
[I consider my answer carefully.] Yes, but their own sort of honor, sire.

Jon Snow.profile:
Jon Snow, a bastard son of Eddard Stark, is a complex and conflicted character in "A Storm of Swords." As a sworn brother of the Night's Watch, Jon finds himself torn between duty and personal desires throughout the novel. With his distinctive Stark features and somber demeanor, Jon possesses a strong sense of honor and loyalty, traits that are constantly tested during his perilous journey beyond the Wall.

Initially sent to infiltrate the wildlings, Jon's mission becomes complicated as he develops genuine connections with the free folk, particularly Ygritte. This relationship forces Jon to confront his vows and identity, leading to intimate encounters that break his Night's Watch oath. His internal struggle between duty and desire forms a central aspect of his character development.

Jon's observant nature and quick wit serve him well as he gathers crucial information about the wildlings' plans and strength. His encounters with giants, mammoths, and the diverse wildling clans expand his worldview and challenge his preconceptions. Throughout his time with the free folk, Jon grapples with questions of loyalty, freedom, and the true nature of the threats facing the realm.

Upon returning to Castle Black, Jon brings vital intelligence about an impending wildling attack, demonstrating his commitment to the Night's Watch despite his conflicted feelings. His experiences beyond the Wall, coupled with the tragic news of losses both personal and within the Watch, further shape his character and perspective.

Jon's role as a negotiator with Mance Rayder highlights his growing importance within the Night's Watch and his ability to navigate complex political situations. His encounter with the alleged Horn of Winter and discussions about the threat of the Others underscore the gravity of the challenges facing both the Watch and the realm.

Throughout the novel, Jon Snow evolves from a dutiful but inexperienced brother of the Night's Watch into a more nuanced and conflicted character. His experiences force him to confront difficult truths about loyalty, duty, and the nature of the threats facing the Seven Kingdoms, setting the stage for his future leadership role within the Night's Watch.

plots.name: Kevan Lannister
plots.description: Tyrion's uncle and brother to Tywin Lannister.
plots.summary: Visits Tyrion in his cell, advising him to confess and take the black. Provides insight into Tywin's character and motivations.

conversations.name: Kevan Lannister
conversations.thought: I'm torn between family loyalty and the weight of evidence against Tyrion. I believe offering him a chance to join the Night's Watch is the best compromise. I must convince him to see reason and accept this opportunity to save his life, even if it means admitting to a crime he may not have committed.

utterances.message: [Time to bring up the Greyjoy situation.] As regards the Starks... Balon Greyjoy has written to us offering terms of alliance.
[This boy is going too far. I must try to reason with him.] Sire, the lady is now your aunt by marriage.
[I should try to emphasize the importance of this gift.] A book every king should read, Your Grace.
[I must convince him to confess for his own good.] Perhaps the time has come for you to confess.

[He needs to understand the gravity of his situation.] If you were to admit your guilt before the throne and repent of your crime, your father would withhold the sword. You would be permitted to take the black.
[I need to distance Tywin from Ned Stark's fate.] Your father had no part in that.
[He's not understanding the gravity of the situation.] Naught was said of forgiveness. A confession would put this matter to rest. It is for that reason your father sends me with this offer.
[He's being stubborn. I need to make him understand the danger he's in.] Were I you, I'd change my mood. Your sister wants your head, and Lord Tyrell at least is inclined to give it to her.

[He's running out of options. I need to make him see reason.] You have no witnesses. Tyrion, if you are guilty of this enormity, the Wall is a kinder fate than you deserve. And if you are blameless... there is fighting in the north, I know, but even so it will be a safer place for you than King's Landing, whatever the outcome of this trial.
[He needs to understand that family still matters.] You are my brother's son.

Kevan Lannister.profile:
Kevan Lannister, brother to Tywin Lannister and uncle to Tyrion, Cersei, and Jaime, is a loyal and pragmatic figure in the Lannister family. As a trusted advisor to his brother, Kevan plays a significant role in the political machinations of King's Landing and the ongoing war efforts against the Starks.

Kevan is characterized by his level-headed approach to complex situations, often serving as a voice of reason amidst the more volatile personalities in the Lannister clan. He demonstrates a keen understanding of political strategy and is not afraid to speak up during Small Council meetings, such as when he brings up the potential alliance with Balon Greyjoy.

Unlike his brother Tywin, Kevan shows a more compassionate side, particularly towards his nephew Tyrion. This is evident when he visits Tyrion in his cell during the trial for Joffrey's murder, offering him a chance to confess and take the black instead of facing execution. His concern for Tyrion's welfare, even while believing in the possibility of his guilt, showcases a nuanced approach to family loyalty.

Kevan's role often involves mediating between the various Lannister factions. He attempts to temper Joffrey's cruel impulses, reminding him of proper behavior towards Sansa Stark. This demonstrates his understanding of the importance of maintaining alliances and appearances, even in the face of victory.

Throughout "A Storm of Swords," Kevan remains a steady presence, providing support to Tywin's rule while navigating the treacherous waters of King's Landing politics. His character serves as a counterpoint to the more extreme elements of the Lannister family, offering a glimpse of what a more measured approach to power might look like in the world of Westeros.

plots.name: Kraznys mo Nakloz
plots.description: A slave trader in Astapor, selling the Unsullied.
plots.summary: Kraznys demonstrates the Unsullied's qualities to Daenerys, highlighting their discipline and obedience while displaying his own cruelty and disdain for the "western whore".

conversations.name: Kraznys mo Nakloz
conversations.thought: This foolish girl thinks she can play in a man's world. I'll show her the true strength of the Unsullied and put her in her place. Perhaps I can manipulate her naivety to my advantage, both in business and pleasure. These barbarians know nothing of real power or the value of what I offer. I must emphasize the Unsullied's obedience and strength to impress this 'queen'.

utterances.message: [This whore knows nothing of real warriors.] Tell the Westerosi whore to lower her eyes. I deal in meat, not metal. The bronze is not for sale. Tell her to look at the soldiers. Even the dim purple eyes of a sunset savage can see how magnificent my creatures are, surely.

[These westerners are all ignorant fools.] Are all Westerosi pigs so ignorant? All the world knows that the Unsullied are masters of spear and shield and shortsword. (to the translator) Tell her what she would know, slave, and be quick about it. The day is hot.

[She understands nothing of true strength.] Inform the savages that we call this obedience. Others may be stronger or quicker or larger than the Unsullied. Some few may even equal their skill with sword and spear and shield. But nowhere between the seas will you ever find any more obedient.

[This old man dares to mock me?] A word from me and these sheep would spill his stinking old bowels on the bricks. (to the translator) But do not say that. Tell them that these creatures are more dogs than sheep. Do they eat dogs or horse in these Seven Kingdoms?

Kraznys mo Nakloz.profile:
Kraznys mo Nakloz is a wealthy and influential slave trader from Astapor, a city renowned for its brutal warrior-eunuchs known as the Unsullied. As one of the Good Masters of Astapor, Kraznys plays a pivotal role in Daenerys Targaryen's journey to build her army. 

Kraznys is characterized by his cruelty, arrogance, and disdain for those he considers beneath him, particularly foreigners. He takes great pride in the Unsullied, viewing them as his prized "creatures" rather than human beings. His interactions with Daenerys reveal a man who is both a shrewd businessman and a misogynist, often referring to her as a "western whore" in his native tongue.

Physically, Kraznys is not described in detail, but his demeanor suggests a man accustomed to power and luxury. He conducts his business in the sweltering Plaza of Pride, unfazed by the heat that affects others, indicating his adaptation to Astapor's climate.

Kraznys's primary motivation appears to be profit and the maintenance of his status as a powerful slave trader. He takes pleasure in demonstrating the Unsullied's discipline and obedience, highlighting their inhumanly cruel training regimen with a sense of pride. His actions and words reveal a man deeply entrenched in the slave trade, seeing it not just as a business but as a way of life that he wholeheartedly embraces.

In the larger narrative, Kraznys serves as a representation of the slave culture that Daenerys confronts in Essos. His interaction with her is a crucial moment in her character development, as she grapples with the moral implications of using a slave army to reclaim her throne in Westeros. Kraznys's arrogance and underestimation of Daenerys ultimately play a significant role in the fate of Astapor and the Unsullied, making him a catalyst for major events in the story.

utterances.message: [We've made our presence known. Now to move things along.] My lord of Lannister, we have come a long dusty way, and rest and refreshment would be most welcome. Might we continue on to the city?
[We've made our presence known. Now to move things along.] My lord of Lannister, we have come a long dusty way, and rest and refreshment would be most welcome. Might we continue on to the city?

Lady Blackmont.profile:
Lady Blackmont is a minor noble character in "A Storm of Swords," the third book in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. As a member of House Blackmont, one of the noble houses of Dorne, she accompanies Prince Oberyn Martell's delegation to King's Landing. While not a central figure in the narrative, Lady Blackmont's presence adds depth to the Dornish contingent and highlights the political complexity of their visit.

Lady Blackmont is portrayed as a practical and diplomatic figure. During the tense first encounter between the Dornish party and Tyrion Lannister outside King's Landing, she demonstrates her pragmatism by suggesting they continue to the city for rest and refreshment. This intervention serves to ease the mounting tension between Oberyn and Tyrion, showcasing her ability to navigate delicate political situations.

Her role in the delegation underscores the united front presented by the Dornish nobles in support of Prince Oberyn's mission to King's Landing. While her personal motivations are not explicitly stated, as a Dornish noblewoman, she likely shares the general Dornish resentment towards the Lannisters and supports Oberyn's quest for justice for his sister Elia.

Lady Blackmont's brief but notable appearance in this scene helps to flesh out the political landscape of Westeros, particularly the complex relationship between Dorne and the rest of the Seven Kingdoms. Her presence reinforces the importance of the Dornish delegation and the potential implications of their visit to the capital.

plots.name: Lady Smallwood
plots.description: The lady of Acorn Hall, who provides hospitality to the outlaws.
plots.summary: Lady Smallwood welcomes the group, provides them with information about recent events, and shows kindness to Arya by giving her proper clothes and a bath.

Lady Smallwood.profile:
Lady Smallwood is a minor yet memorable character in "A Storm of Swords," the third installment of George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. As the lady of Acorn Hall, she plays a brief but significant role in Arya Stark's journey through the war-torn Riverlands. Lady Smallwood embodies the nobility and hospitality that still exists in Westeros, even in times of conflict.

Known for her kindness and generosity, Lady Smallwood provides crucial support to the group of outlaws traveling with Arya. Her willingness to offer shelter and information to these men, who are effectively operating outside the law, demonstrates both her compassion and her pragmatism in navigating the complex political landscape of the war.

Lady Smallwood's most notable interaction is with Arya herself. Recognizing the young girl's true status despite her disguise, she takes it upon herself to provide Arya with proper clothing and a much-needed bath. This act of motherly care offers a brief respite for Arya from the harsh realities of her journey and serves as a poignant reminder of the life she left behind.

While her appearance in the story is limited, Lady Smallwood's role highlights the importance of allies and safe havens in the dangerous world of Westeros. Her actions contribute to the broader narrative by providing a moment of refuge and normalcy in Arya's tumultuous adventure, as well as offering valuable information about recent events, including rumors of Jaime Lannister's escape.

plots.name: Lark the Sisterman
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch from the Three Sisters islands.
plots.summary: Lark is part of Chett's mutiny plot. He plans to sail back to the Sisters after deserting, though Chett thinks this is foolish.

conversations.name: Lark the Sisterman
conversations.thought: I'm freezing and impatient for this mutiny to be over. I can't wait to sail back to the Sisters and leave this frozen hell behind. These fools I'm stuck with are driving me mad. I hope taunting them will make the time pass quicker, even if it's dangerous.

utterances.message: [Finally. My fingers feel like they're about to fall off.] It's too bloody cold to hunt. Bugger this bear, he's not worth freezing over.
[This simpleton doesn't understand anything.] Bugger that Old Bear too. Mormont will be dead before daybreak, remember? Who cares what he likes?
[Gods, he's thick.] You think he'll let us be? He'll hunt us down. You want to be hunted, you great muttonhead?
[Maybe if I put it simply...] So you'll kill him?
[Now to push for more. The more chaos, the better our chances.] We need to kill all the officers, I say.
[This big oaf is hopeless.] (laughs) Small Paul, thick as a castle wall.
[Maybe this will get a rise out of the big idiot.] We can always eat him if we get hungry.

Lark the Sisterman.profile:
Lark the Sisterman is a minor but notable character in "A Storm of Swords," the third book in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A brother of the Night's Watch hailing from the Three Sisters islands, Lark is part of a secret mutiny plot against Lord Commander Mormont and other officers during a ranging expedition beyond the Wall.

Portrayed as a disgruntled and impatient man, Lark is eager to desert the Night's Watch and return to his homeland. His involvement in Chett's conspiracy reveals his dissatisfaction with life at the Wall and his willingness to betray his vows for a chance at freedom. Lark's interactions with his fellow conspirators demonstrate a sharp tongue and a penchant for mockery, particularly towards Small Paul, whom he taunts for his perceived lack of intelligence.

Lark's motivations seem primarily driven by self-interest and a desire to escape the harsh conditions of the North. He shows little loyalty to the Night's Watch or its mission, instead focusing on his own survival and comfort. His plan to sail back to the Sisters after deserting is viewed as foolish by Chett, hinting at Lark's potential for poor decision-making or unrealistic expectations.

In the tense atmosphere leading up to the planned mutiny, Lark's impatience and loose tongue pose a risk to the conspirators' secrecy. His callous attitude towards killing the Lord Commander and other officers, as well as his suggestion to kill all officers, reveals a ruthless streak and a disregard for the consequences of his actions.

While Lark's ultimate fate is not detailed in the provided information, his involvement in this dangerous plot places him at the center of a pivotal moment in the Night's Watch's history, as they face threats from both within their ranks and from the approaching wildling army.

plots.name: Lem
plots.description: A large soldier wearing a yellow cloak.
plots.summary: Lem appears intimidating but follows Tom's lead in the conversation.

utterances.message: [I'll play along with Tom's approach.] I heard.

Lem.profile:
Lem is a minor yet memorable character in "A Storm of Swords," the third installment of George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A large, imposing figure, Lem is easily recognizable by his distinctive yellow cloak, which has become something of a trademark. He appears as part of a trio alongside Tom Sevenstrings and Anguy, encountering Arya Stark and her companions in the war-torn Riverlands.

While not the leader of his group, Lem presents an intimidating presence that contrasts with Tom's more diplomatic approach. His physical stature and warrior-like demeanor suggest a background in combat, fitting for the dangerous times in which the story takes place. Lem seems content to follow Tom's lead in conversations, indicating a hierarchical structure within their group or perhaps a recognition of Tom's superior social skills.

Lem's interactions with Arya and her friends reveal a complex character beneath his gruff exterior. While he initially appears threatening, he shows restraint and a willingness to engage in dialogue rather than immediate violence. This suggests a nuanced personality that balances the necessities of survival in a harsh world with a underlying sense of honor or fairness.

As part of what appears to be a band of outlaws or irregular soldiers, Lem plays a role in the broader tapestry of the war-ravaged countryside. His presence highlights the breakdown of traditional power structures and the rise of autonomous groups operating in the power vacuum left by the ongoing conflicts.

While Lem's full backstory and motivations remain somewhat mysterious in this encounter, his association with Tom and Anguy, and their claim to be "king's men," hints at a possible connection to larger political or military factions within the realm. His character serves to illustrate the complex and often ambiguous allegiances that exist in the chaotic world of "A Song of Ice and Fire."

plots.name: Lommy
plots.description: Another young boy traveling with Arya's group.
plots.summary: Lommy is mentioned as one of Arya's companions, but his specific actions are not detailed in this excerpt.

utterances.message: [I don't understand what she means.] (Confused) Wrong side? What do you mean?

Lommy.profile:
Lommy is a minor character in "A Storm of Swords," the third book in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. He is a young boy who travels with Arya Stark and a group of other children as they flee from danger in King's Landing. While not much is known about Lommy's background or physical appearance, he is portrayed as one of the vulnerable youths caught up in the turmoil of war-torn Westeros.

In the group dynamic, Lommy appears to be less assertive or knowledgeable compared to Arya. When Arya notices that they are heading in the wrong direction based on the moss growing on trees, Lommy expresses confusion, asking for clarification about what she means by the "wrong side." This interaction suggests that Lommy lacks some of the survival skills and observational abilities that Arya possesses.

Lommy's presence in the story primarily serves to illustrate the plight of common children during times of conflict and to provide a contrast to Arya's more resourceful and perceptive nature. His character helps to highlight Arya's unique capabilities and her struggle to conceal her true identity and education while guiding her companions to safety.

While Lommy's individual motivations and character arc are not prominently featured in the provided excerpt, his inclusion in the group underscores the harsh realities faced by young, displaced individuals in the world of "A Song of Ice and Fire." His character contributes to the overall atmosphere of vulnerability and uncertainty that permeates Arya's journey.

utterances.message: [We need to emphasize Jon's value to ensure he's taken to Mance.] He slew Qhorin Halfhand. Him and that wolf o' his.

Longspear Ryk.profile:
Longspear Ryk is a minor character in "A Storm of Swords," serving as a member of the wildling group led by Rattleshirt. While details about his background and physical appearance are limited, his name suggests he may be skilled with a spear. Ryk plays a small but notable role in Jon Snow's storyline as the latter infiltrates the wildling camp.

As part of Rattleshirt's band, Longspear Ryk is present when Jon Snow is brought to Mance Rayder's camp as a supposed turncloak from the Night's Watch. Ryk demonstrates a degree of awareness about Jon's accomplishments, particularly highlighting Jon's defeat of Qhorin Halfhand to emphasize Jon's value to the wildling cause. This suggests Ryk is observant and understands the importance of leveraging information to their advantage.

Ryk's interactions reveal him to be a loyal member of the Free Folk, working in tandem with his fellow wildlings to navigate the complex dynamics of their society. His willingness to speak up about Jon's deeds indicates a certain level of confidence and an understanding of the political landscape within the wildling ranks.

While Longspear Ryk's character arc and deeper motivations are not extensively explored in the narrative, his brief appearance provides insight into the collaborative nature of the wildling groups and their process of integrating potential new members. His role, though small, contributes to the tension and intrigue surrounding Jon Snow's precarious position among the Free Folk.

plots.name: Loras Tyrell
plots.description: Young and skilled knight of the Kingsguard, formerly loyal to Renly Baratheon.
plots.summary: Clashes with Jaime over their respective skills and experiences, defends his loyalty to Renly, and reluctantly reveals the truth about Renly's armor at the Battle of the Blackwater.

conversations.name: Loras Tyrell
conversations.thought: I must stand my ground against the Kingslayer's interrogation while navigating the delicate balance between honoring Renly's memory and my current duties. His questions feel like attacks, and I'm determined to prove my worth. Yet, I must be cautious not to reveal too much about my past or my family's ambitions.

utterances.message: [He's trying to make me feel small. I won't let him.] Yes, my lord.
[Two can play at this game.] That as well, my lord. (smiles)
[I won't back down from his challenge.] And now you're older. My lord.
[I'll turn his words against him.] As you learned from Ser Boros and Ser Meryn?
[I won't be intimidated by ghosts.] Dead men, every one.
[I can't refuse to answer, but I don't have to like it.] My brother. Renly was taller than me, and broader in the chest. His armor was too loose on me, but it suited Garlan well.

Loras Tyrell.profile:
Ser Loras Tyrell, known as the Knight of Flowers, is a young and exceptionally skilled member of the Kingsguard in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords." Hailing from the powerful House Tyrell, Loras is characterized by his youth, ambition, and formidable martial prowess. At just seventeen, he achieved the remarkable feat of being appointed to the Kingsguard, matching the age of the legendary Prince Aemon the Dragonknight upon his appointment.

Loras is known for his pride and confidence, traits that often manifest as insolence when dealing with authority figures. This is evident in his tense interactions with Jaime Lannister, the new Lord Commander of the Kingsguard. Despite his youth, Loras shows no hesitation in verbally sparring with the more experienced Jaime, demonstrating both his quick wit and his unwillingness to be intimidated.

Prior to his appointment to the Kingsguard, Loras was a devoted supporter of Renly Baratheon, showcasing his capacity for deep loyalty. This allegiance to Renly continues to influence his actions and attitudes even after joining the Kingsguard, as he staunchly defends Renly's memory when questioned by Jaime.

Loras's combat skills are widely acknowledged, with reports of his magnificent performance in battle. His prowess is such that he is compared favorably to legendary knights of the past, though he himself seems more focused on the present and future than on the legacy of fallen heroes.

A key aspect of Loras's character is his involvement in political machinations. He played a significant role in the Battle of the Blackwater, where his brother Garlan wore Renly's armor to boost morale. This deception, reluctantly revealed to Jaime, highlights the complex interplay between Loras's personal loyalties, family ambitions, and his new duties as a Kingsguard.

Throughout the story, Loras grapples with balancing his past allegiances and personal desires with his sworn duties, embodying the conflicts faced by many young nobles in the tumultuous world of Westeros. His character arc suggests a journey from a brash, idealistic young knight to a more complex figure navigating the treacherous waters of power and duty in King's Landing.

plots.name: Beric Dondarrion
plots.description: The leader of the Brotherhood without Banners, who has been resurrected multiple times.
plots.summary: Beric leads the attack on the Brave Companions, discusses his resurrections with Thoros, and knights Gendry. He promises to return Arya to her family.

conversations.name: Beric Dondarrion
conversations.thought: Weary from multiple resurrections, I feel the weight of my duty. The girl's safety is paramount, but our cause needs funds. I must balance our needs with her welfare, hoping to offer comfort despite my own doubts. Her innocence reminds me of what we fight for.

utterances.message: [The child's pain is palpable. I must offer some comfort.] Your father was a good man. Harwin has told me much of him. For his sake, I would gladly forgo your ransom, but we need the gold too desperately.
[She fears rejection from her own family. I must reassure her.] Why would you think that?

[I must make a solemn promise to reassure her.] (sighs) Then I will send you to Lady Smallwood for a time, or perhaps to mine own castle of Blackhaven. But that will not be necessary, I'm certain. I do not have the power to give you back your father, no more than Thoros does, but I can at least see that you are returned safely to your mother's arms.
[I will honor this vow with my life.] On my honor as a knight.

Beric Dondarrion.profile:
Beric Dondarrion is a complex and enigmatic figure in "A Storm of Swords," serving as the leader of the Brotherhood without Banners. Once a young, handsome lord, Beric's appearance has been dramatically altered by his multiple deaths and resurrections, each leaving him more haggard and worn. His most striking feature is the eye patch covering the socket where his left eye once was, a testament to the toll his supernatural experiences have taken on his body.

As the Lightning Lord, Beric leads his band of outlaws with a strong sense of justice and duty, fighting against those who prey on the weak during the War of the Five Kings. His leadership is characterized by a blend of knightly honor and pragmatic decision-making, as evidenced by his balanced approach to Arya Stark's situation – recognizing her value as a hostage while also genuinely caring for her welfare.

Beric's most defining attribute is his repeated resurrections, performed by the red priest Thoros of Myr through the power of R'hllor. These experiences have profoundly impacted him, leaving him with a unique perspective on life, death, and purpose. He speaks of his resurrections with a mix of weariness and wonder, aware of the unnatural nature of his continued existence.

Despite the toll of his supernatural ordeals, Beric maintains a strong moral compass and a commitment to protecting the innocent. This is exemplified in his promise to return Arya to her family, even offering to forgo her ransom if not for the Brotherhood's desperate need for funds. His interactions with Arya reveal a gentle, paternal side, as he attempts to comfort and reassure the young girl despite his own doubts and burdens.

Beric's character arc in the story is one of gradual diminishment, each resurrection stripping away more of his former self while leaving his core values intact. Yet, he perseveres in his mission, embodying the resilience of the human spirit in the face of extraordinary circumstances. His willingness to knight Gendry demonstrates his belief in the ideals of chivalry, even in a world torn apart by war and treachery.

In essence, Beric Dondarrion stands as a symbol of enduring hope and justice in a harsh world, his very existence a testament to the mysterious forces at play in the realm of Westeros.

plots.name: Rickard Karstark
plots.description: Lord of Karhold, grieving father seeking vengeance.
plots.summary: Defends his actions in killing the squires, viewing it as just vengeance for his sons' deaths, showing no remorse despite Robb's condemnation.

conversations.name: Rickard Karstark
conversations.thought: I feel no remorse for what I've done. These Lannister boys' deaths are just vengeance for my sons, cut down by the Kingslayer. I'm prepared to face the consequences of my actions, for nothing can take away the satisfaction of this revenge. Let the Young Wolf do what he will; I stand firm in my conviction that only blood can pay for blood.

utterances.message: [Anger and grief fuel my words.] Aye, my lady. And I have one son, who once had three. You have robbed me of my vengeance.
[My grief turns to bitterness.] Jaime Lannister has played you for a fool. You've bought a bag of empty words, no more. My Torrhen and my Eddard deserved better of you.
[My anger flares at the dismissal.] A mother's folly? I name it treason.
[I feel no shame for what I've done. Let them all hear my justification.] It was no murder, ser. Any man who steps between a father and his vengeance asks for death.
[Nothing he says can change how I feel.] They died. The Kingslayer cut them down. These two were of his ilk. Only blood can pay for blood.
[I will not back down. Let him see the steel in my resolve.] Squires die in every battle.

Rickard Karstark.profile:
Rickard Karstark, Lord of Karhold, is a formidable and grief-stricken figure in "A Storm of Swords." A bannerman to House Stark, Karstark's unwavering loyalty is shattered by personal tragedy. After losing two sons, Torrhen and Eddard, in battle against the Lannisters, Karstark becomes consumed by a thirst for vengeance that ultimately leads him down a path of dishonor and betrayal.

Driven by raw emotion and a twisted sense of justice, Karstark's actions exemplify the devastating impact of war on even the most steadfast allies. His grief manifests as a bitter, unyielding rage that blinds him to reason and honor. This is evident in his confrontation with Catelyn Stark, where he accuses her of robbing him of his vengeance by releasing Jaime Lannister.

Karstark's descent into vengeance reaches its nadir when he orchestrates the murder of two young Lannister squires, Tion Frey and Willem Lannister, who were unarmed prisoners. This act, which he defiantly justifies as righteous retribution, marks a critical turning point in his relationship with Robb Stark and the Northern cause.

In the face of Robb's condemnation, Karstark remains unrepentant, declaring, "It was no murder, ser. Any man who steps between a father and his vengeance asks for death." His stubborn insistence that "only blood can pay for blood" showcases his unwillingness to distinguish between combatants and innocent children, highlighting the dangerous extremes of his grief-fueled vendetta.

Karstark's arc serves as a stark reminder of how personal loss can corrode loyalty and honor, transforming a once-faithful ally into a liability. His actions force Robb Stark to confront difficult questions of justice, mercy, and the costs of maintaining unity in wartime, adding to the complex political landscape of the North's rebellion.

plots.name: Tywin Lannister
plots.description: Hand of the King and Tyrion's father.
plots.summary: Tywin is confronted by Tyrion in the privy and is killed with a crossbow bolt.

plots.name: Tywin Lannister
plots.description: Lord of Casterly Rock and Hand of the King, Tyrion's father.
plots.summary: Tywin is cold and dismissive towards Tyrion, focused on consolidating Lannister power after the battle.

plots.name: Tywin Lannister
plots.description: Patriarch of House Lannister, Hand of the King.
plots.summary: Leads the council meeting, making key decisions about war strategy and alliances.

plots.name: Tywin Lannister
plots.description: Patriarch of House Lannister and Hand of the King.
plots.summary: Tywin reveals his strategic plans following Robb Stark's death, including how to handle the Dornish and consolidate power in the North.

plots.name: Tywin Lannister
plots.description: Powerful patriarch of House Lannister, Hand of the King.
plots.summary: Tywin attempts to manipulate Jaime into leaving the Kingsguard and becoming his heir. He disowns Jaime when he refuses to comply with his wishes.

plots.name: Tywin Lannister
plots.description: Hand of the King and Tyrion's father, presiding over the trial.
plots.summary: Leads the trial against his son, maintaining a stern and impartial demeanor throughout the proceedings.

conversations.name: Tywin Lannister
conversations.thought: I'm caught off guard and vulnerable, but I must maintain control. Tyrion is unpredictable and dangerous. I need to diffuse this situation without losing my authority. His fixation on that girl from his past is irritating and beneath my concern.

conversations.name: Tywin Lannister
conversations.thought: Tyrion's presence is an unwelcome distraction from crucial matters of state. I must manage him efficiently, providing minimal information to satisfy his curiosity without encouraging further disruption. His role in the battle was necessary, but I won't let it inflate his importance.

conversations.name: Tywin Lannister
conversations.thought: As Hand of the King, I must steer this council decisively. Our recent victory is promising, but Robb Stark remains a threat. I need to balance immediate war strategy with long-term political maneuvers. Balon Greyjoy's offer and the Vale situation require careful consideration. I must project strength and control throughout this meeting.

conversations.name: Tywin Lannister
conversations.thought: This victory must be leveraged carefully to cement our family's power. I need to control Joffrey's impulsiveness and ensure our allies are appeased. The Dornish situation requires delicate handling. How can I manipulate events to further strengthen House Lannister's position while maintaining stability in the realm?

utterances.message: [I'm surprised but trying to maintain my composure.] Tyrion. (He raises his eyes) Who released you from your cell?
[I'm irritated by his insolence.] The eunuch. I'll have his head for this. (He notices the weapon) Is that my crossbow? Put it down.

[I try to reason with him, maintaining my authority.] This escape is folly. You are not to be killed, if that is what you fear. It's still my intent to send you to the Wall, but I could not do it without Lord Tyrell's consent. Put down the crossbow and we will go back to my chambers and talk of it.
[I'm growing impatient with this game.] I owe you nothing.
[I'm caught off guard by the question.] Tysha?
[I dismiss her importance.] Oh, yes. Your first whore.
[I refuse to show fear.] You do not have the courage.
[I try to evade the question.] I don't recall.

[I give a partial answer, still trying to maintain control.] There was no reason for that, she'd learned her place... and had been well paid for her day's work, I seem to recall. I suppose the steward sent her on her way. I never thought to inquire.
[I give a dismissive answer.] Wherever whores go.
[I feel shock and disbelief as life ebbs from me.] You... you are no... no son of mine.
[I won't dignify his japes with a response.] (ignores the comment) You had best be seated. Is it wise for you to be out of your sickbed?
[He's fishing for sympathy. I won't give him the satisfaction.] The Red Keep is overcrowded with wedding guests. Once they depart, we will find you more suitable accommodations.

[He's behind on events. I'll enlighten him, but briefly.] Joffrey and Margaery shall marry on the first day of the new year, which as it happens is also the first day of the new century. The ceremony will herald the dawn of a new era.
[His japes grow tiresome.] Did you come here just to complain of your bedchamber and make your lame japes? I have important letters to finish.

[He needs to understand the gravity of our situation.] Some battles are won with swords and spears, others with quills and ravens. Spare me these coy reproaches, Tyrion. I visited your sickbed as often as Maester Ballabar would allow it, when you seemed like to die.
[I must assert control immediately.] We begin with the war. Varys, report.
[I'll demonstrate my strategic thinking.] He has run back to Riverrun with his plunder, abandoning the castles he took in the west. Our forces are regrouping to strike when he moves north.
[My daughter lacks subtlety. I must explain the realities.] By right of conquest. King Balon holds significant territory and poses a threat we cannot ignore.

[This foolish boy will undo everything if I don't intervene.] Joffrey, when your enemies defy you, you must serve them steel and fire. When they go to their knees, however, you must help them back to their feet. Elsewise no man will ever bend the knee to you. And any man who must say 'I am the king' is no true king at all.
