[It's time to present my gift and perhaps redirect Joffrey's attention.] Your Grace, I present you with this longsword. (presents an ornate Valyrian steel sword)

Tywin Lannister.profile:
Tywin Lannister, the formidable patriarch of House Lannister and Hand of the King, is a towering figure in the political landscape of Westeros. A man of imposing presence and unwavering resolve, Tywin's every action is calculated to further the power and legacy of his family. His cold, analytical demeanor masks a ruthless pragmatism that has made him one of the most feared and respected lords in the Seven Kingdoms.

As Lord of Casterly Rock and Warden of the West, Tywin commands vast wealth and military might. His strategic acumen is evident in his handling of both war and politics, always seeking to position the Lannisters advantageously. Tywin's involvement in orchestrating events like the Red Wedding demonstrates his willingness to employ brutal tactics to achieve his goals.

In his role as Hand of the King, Tywin effectively rules the realm, making crucial decisions about alliances, war strategy, and the consolidation of power. He navigates complex political situations with a combination of intimidation, negotiation, and cunning, always keeping the long-term interests of House Lannister at the forefront.

Tywin's relationships with his children are complex and fraught with tension. He is particularly dismissive and cruel towards Tyrion, whom he sees as a disappointment and a threat to the family's reputation. This strained relationship reaches its breaking point when Tyrion, driven by a lifetime of resentment and a desperate need for answers about his past, confronts and ultimately kills Tywin.

Throughout "A Storm of Swords," Tywin's actions and decisions shape the course of events in Westeros. His strategic marriages, political maneuverings, and military campaigns solidify Lannister power in the aftermath of the War of the Five Kings. However, his rigid worldview and inability to see value in those he deems unworthy, particularly his own son Tyrion, ultimately lead to his downfall.

Tywin Lannister embodies the ruthless pursuit of power and family legacy, leaving an indelible mark on the political landscape of Westeros even after his death. His complex character serves as a driving force in the novel, illustrating the often brutal nature of power and the far-reaching consequences of familial dysfunction in the game of thrones.

plots.name: Lysa Arryn
plots.description: Widow of Jon Arryn, Lady of the Eyrie, and Sansa's aunt.
plots.summary: Arrives at the Fingers and immediately marries Petyr Baelish, showing her long-held passion and obsession for him.

plots.name: Lysa Arryn
plots.description: Catelyn Stark's sister and Lady of the Vale.
plots.summary: Lysa confronts Sansa in a jealous rage, reveals past secrets, and is ultimately murdered by Petyr Baelish, whom she trusted and loved.

conversations.name: Lysa Arryn
conversations.thought: My mind is consumed by jealousy and betrayal. I'm convinced Sansa is trying to steal Petyr from me, just like Catelyn did years ago. I'll make her confess and punish her for her wantonness. I must protect what's mine at all costs, even if it means resorting to extreme measures. My emotions are spiraling out of control.

conversations.name: Lysa Arryn
conversations.thought: Petyr's arrival fills me with a mix of hope and vindication. I'm certain he'll understand my actions and support me. My love for him is all-consuming, and I'm desperate to prove my devotion. The girl threatens everything we've built together. I must make Petyr see that I'm the only one who truly loves and understands him.

utterances.message: [My blood is boiling with jealousy and rage. I'll make this little harlot pay for trying to seduce my Petyr.] You threw yourself at him. That was the way of it.
[She dares to deny it? I'll show her how serious I am.] Where are you going? Are you afraid? Such wanton behavior must be punished, but I will not be hard on you.
[Her words only fuel my anger and paranoia.] Have you no honor? Or do you take me for a fool? You do, don't you? You take me for a fool. Yes, I see that now.

[The memories of Catelyn's closeness with Petyr resurface, intensifying my jealousy.] Yes, your mother, your precious mother, my own sweet sister Catelyn. Don't you think to play the innocent with me, you vile little liar.
[My rage is reaching its peak. I'll make her understand the depth of my pain and jealousy.] How would you know? Were you there? (She grabs Sansa and starts pushing her towards the Moon Door)
[My heart leaps at Petyr's arrival. Now he'll see how much I love him.] Her. She's the trouble. She kissed you.
[How dare this girl speak! My anger flares again.] Be quiet! I never gave you leave to speak. No one cares about your castle.
[I feel a mix of defiance and desperation.] I was going to marry her to Robert! She has no gratitude. No... no decency. You are not hers to kiss. Not hers! I was teaching her a lesson, that was all.
[My emotions are in turmoil. I feel possessive and insecure.] I don't want her here. Why did you bring her to the Vale, Petyr? This isn't her place. She doesn't belong here.

[Panic sets in as I fear losing Petyr.] NO! (She wrenches Sansa's head) You can't want her. You can't. She's a stupid empty-headed little girl. She doesn't love you the way I have. I've always loved you. I've proved it, haven't I?

[My desperation grows as I recall all I've done for Petyr.] Cat never gave you anything. It was me who got you your first post, who made Jon bring you to court so we could be close to one another. You promised me you would never forget that.

[My emotions overwhelm me as I reveal our darkest secrets.] Tears, tears, tears. No need for tears... but that's not what you said in King's Landing. You told me to put the tears in Jon's wine, and I did. For Robert, and for us!
[Hope blossoms in my chest. Could this be true?] Truly? Oh, truly?
[My heart soars with joy and relief.] Only one? Oh, Petyr, do you swear it? Only one?

Lysa Arryn.profile:
Lysa Arryn, née Tully, is a complex and volatile character in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords." As the widow of Jon Arryn, the former Hand of the King, and Lady of the Eyrie, Lysa plays a significant role in the political landscape of Westeros. She is the sister of Catelyn Stark and aunt to Sansa Stark, though her actions are often driven by her own desires rather than familial loyalty.

Physically, Lysa is described as having the Tully features of auburn hair and blue eyes, though years of childbearing and stress have taken their toll on her once-comely appearance. Her most defining characteristic, however, is her unstable and paranoid personality, which has been shaped by years of personal traumas and unrequited love.

Lysa's core motivation revolves around her lifelong obsession with Petyr Baelish, whom she has loved since childhood. This passion leads her to make rash decisions, including her hasty marriage to Petyr at his ancestral home in the Fingers. Her impulsive nature and emotional instability are evident in her quick transition from widowhood to a new marriage, highlighting her desperate need for Petyr's affection.

Throughout the story, Lysa's actions are often unpredictable and driven by jealousy, fear, and a desire for control. Her relationship with her son, Robert Arryn, is notably unhealthy, as she coddles and overprotects him to an extreme degree. This behavior, coupled with her paranoia about perceived threats to her power and her son's inheritance, makes her a dangerous and unpredictable ally or enemy.

Lysa's significance in the plot is primarily tied to her control of the Eyrie and the Vale, as well as her connection to key players like Petyr Baelish and the Stark family. Her actions and decisions have far-reaching consequences for the political machinations unfolding across Westeros, making her a pivotal, if unstable, figure in the ongoing power struggles of the realm.

utterances.message: [I should contribute something.] Is there anything as pointless as a king without a kingdom? No, it's plain, the boy must abandon the riverlands and throw all his strength against Moat Cailin.

Mace Tyrell.profile:
Mace Tyrell, Lord of Highgarden and Warden of the South, is a prominent figure in the political landscape of Westeros during the War of the Five Kings. As the head of House Tyrell, one of the most powerful and wealthy families in the Seven Kingdoms, Mace wields considerable influence, though his capabilities as a leader are often questioned by more astute observers.

Physically imposing but intellectually unremarkable, Mace Tyrell is known for his pompous demeanor and inflated sense of self-importance. His contributions to small council meetings, as evidenced in "A Storm of Swords," often reveal a lack of strategic acumen and a tendency to state the obvious. For instance, his suggestion that Robb Stark must abandon the riverlands and focus on Moat Cailin demonstrates a surface-level understanding of military strategy that fails to account for the young wolf's proven capabilities.

Despite his shortcomings, Mace's position as the patriarch of House Tyrell makes him a crucial ally for the Lannisters in their war efforts. His family's vast resources and military strength are essential to maintaining control over the Seven Kingdoms. However, it is often suggested that the true political savvy of House Tyrell lies with Mace's mother, Olenna Tyrell, known as the Queen of Thorns, and his daughter Margaery, rather than with Mace himself.

Throughout the series, Mace's primary motivation appears to be elevating the status of House Tyrell and securing advantageous marriages for his children, particularly Margaery's union with the crown. His presence on the small council underscores the Tyrell family's growing influence in King's Landing, though his contributions to governance and war strategy are often overshadowed by more capable council members.

While not a central character in driving the plot, Mace Tyrell's role as a powerful lord and father to key players like Margaery makes him an important figure in the complex political machinations of "A Storm of Swords" and the broader Song of Ice and Fire series.

plots.name: Aemon
plots.description: The elderly, blind maester of Castle Black.
plots.summary: Aemon tends to Jon's wounds and informs him of the tragic events that occurred during his absence.

conversations.name: Aemon
conversations.thought: Jon's condition is grave, but the urgency in his voice cannot be ignored. I must balance tending to his physical wounds with extracting vital information. The burden of the tragic news we must share with him weighs heavily on my heart. How will he react to the losses we've suffered?

utterances.message: [The boy's wound is severe, but his information is vital.] Easy, Jon. Try not to move. Can you tell us more about these wildlings?
[This news will be difficult for him to hear.] Jon... it grieves me to say, but Lord Commander Mormont was murdered at Craster's Keep, at the hands of his Sworn Brothers.
[I must tread carefully with this information.] For the nonce, until we can hold a choosing. But Jon, there's more you need to know...

Aemon.profile:
Maester Aemon is a venerable and wise figure in the Night's Watch, serving as the elderly, blind maester of Castle Black. Despite his physical limitations, Aemon's intellect and experience make him an invaluable advisor and healer. His gentle demeanor belies a sharp mind that has witnessed decades of history unfold at the Wall.

As a maester, Aemon's primary role is to tend to the health and well-being of the Night's Watch brothers. His medical expertise is evident in his careful treatment of Jon Snow's wounds upon the young man's return from beyond the Wall. Aemon's approach to healing goes beyond the physical; he shows a deep understanding of the emotional toll that recent events have taken on Jon and others at Castle Black.

Aemon's wisdom and calm presence provide a stabilizing force during tumultuous times. He carefully balances the need for urgent information with concern for Jon's condition, demonstrating his ability to prioritize both immediate threats and individual care. His measured way of delivering difficult news, such as the death of Lord Commander Mormont, reflects his compassionate nature and long experience in dealing with the harsh realities of life at the Wall.

The maester's role extends beyond that of a healer; he serves as a crucial source of knowledge and counsel for the Night's Watch. His involvement in discussions about leadership and strategy, such as the temporary command structure following Mormont's death, highlights his importance in the organization's decision-making process.

Aemon's character embodies the enduring strength and resilience of the Night's Watch. Despite his advanced age and blindness, he remains an active and vital part of Castle Black's operations, adapting to challenges and providing guidance through uncertain times. His presence adds depth to the narrative, offering a link to the past and a voice of reason in the face of mounting threats to the realm.

plots.name: Mance Rayder
plots.description: The King-beyond-the-Wall, a former brother of the Night's Watch who became leader of the wildlings.
plots.summary: Mance reveals his cunning and perceptiveness, showing that he recognizes Jon from past encounters. He tests Jon's story and motives, demonstrating his leadership skills and caution in dealing with potential threats or valuable allies.

plots.name: Mance Rayder
plots.description: The King-beyond-the-Wall, leader of the wildlings.
plots.summary: Mance reveals the Horn of Winter and offers a deal to the Night's Watch, showing his strategic thinking and desire to protect his people.

conversations.name: Mance Rayder
conversations.thought: This young crow could be a valuable asset or a dangerous spy. I need to test his resolve, uncover his true motives, and determine if he's genuinely turned his cloak. My past observations of him at Winterfell give me an advantage. I'm intrigued by his potential but wary of deception. This conversation could shape the future of my people's survival.

conversations.name: Mance Rayder
conversations.thought: This is our last chance for survival. I must convince this stubborn crow to let us pass the Wall, or my people will perish. The Horn is our trump card, but using it would be disastrous. I need to make Jon understand the gravity of our situation and the threat of the Others without revealing all our weaknesses. Can I trust him to see reason?

utterances.message: [I'll start with a direct question to gauge his reaction.] Where did you come from?
[Let's see how he handles a more probing question.] And what brings you up the Milkwater, so far from the fires of home?
[Time to reveal some of what I know.] I know your face. I've seen it before. Twice.

[He's quick. Let's see how he handles more details.] Very good! Yes, that was the first time. You were just a boy, and I was all in black, one of a dozen riding escort to old Lord Commander Qorgyle when he came down to see your father at Winterfell.
[He's playing along well. Time for the second encounter.] And kept my vow. That one, at least. The second time I saw you was when King Robert came to Winterfell to make your father Hand.

[Now for the real test.] (explains his disguise and visit in detail) So there you are. The night your father feasted Robert, I sat in the back of his hall on a bench with the other freeriders, listening to Orland of Oldtown play the high harp and sing of dead kings beneath the sea.
[He's quick-witted. Now for the direct question.] So tell me truly, Jon Snow. Are you a craven who turned your cloak from fear, or is there another reason that brings you to my tent?
[He's cunning. This requires a private conversation.] (to Rattleshirt) I would speak with the lad alone, my Lord of Bones. Leave us, all of you.
[I must show him the gravity of our situation.] You must be very brave or very stupid, Jon Snow, to come back to us wearing a black cloak.
[He's as stubborn as ever. I'll need to reveal our trump card.] (He gestures to the massive horn) Yes, the Horn of Winter, that Joramun once blew to wake giants from the earth.
[I need to make him understand the stakes.] Did you think only crows could lie? I liked you well enough, for a bastard... but I never trusted you. A man needs to earn my trust.

[I'll explain our strategy and the real threat we face.] No man goes hunting with only one arrow in his quiver. I had hoped that Styr and Jarl would take your brothers unawares, and open the gate for us. I drew your garrison away with feints and raids and secondary attacks.

[I must make him understand our true motivation.] Blood. I'd win in the end, yes, but you'd bleed me, and my people have bled enough. (His face darkens) The Others grow stronger as the days grow shorter and the nights colder. First they kill you, then they send your dead against you.

[I must swallow my pride and admit our weakness.] Nor me. (His voice filled with bitterness) Raymun Redbeard, Bael the Bard, Gendel and Gorne, the Horned Lord, they all came south to conquer, but I've come with my tail between my legs to hide behind your Wall.
[I'll make my final offer.] Go back and tell them to open their gate and let us pass. If they do, I will give them the horn, and the Wall will stand until the end of days.

[I must assert our independence while offering cooperation.] Whose laws? The laws of Winterfell and King's Landing? (He laughs) When we want laws we'll make our own. You can keep your king's justice too, and your king's taxes. I'm offering you the horn, not our freedom. We will not kneel to you.

Mance Rayder.profile:
Mance Rayder, known as the King-beyond-the-Wall, is a complex and enigmatic figure in "A Storm of Swords." A former brother of the Night's Watch who turned his cloak, Mance has united the diverse wildling clans under his leadership. His physical appearance is not explicitly described, but he carries himself with the confidence and charisma befitting a king.

Mance is characterized by his sharp intellect, perceptiveness, and strategic thinking. He possesses a unique blend of wildling freedom and the knowledge gained from his time in the Night's Watch, making him a formidable leader. His ability to recognize Jon Snow from past encounters demonstrates his keen memory and attention to detail.

As a leader, Mance is cautious yet decisive, carefully assessing potential threats and allies. He shows a willingness to negotiate and seek peaceful solutions, as evidenced by his offer to trade the Horn of Winter for safe passage through the Wall. This reveals his primary motivation: the survival and protection of his people in the face of the growing threat from the Others.

Mance's character is marked by a deep understanding of both wildling and Westerosi cultures, allowing him to bridge the gap between these two worlds. He values freedom above all else, refusing to kneel to southern kings while still recognizing the need for some form of law and order among his people.

Throughout the story, Mance plays a pivotal role in the conflict between the wildlings and the Night's Watch. His possession of the Horn of Winter and his massive army make him a significant threat to the Seven Kingdoms. However, his actions are driven by desperation and a genuine desire to save his people from the encroaching darkness beyond the Wall.

Mance's character arc reveals a leader grappling with the weight of responsibility and the harsh realities of survival in a world threatened by supernatural forces. His interactions with Jon Snow showcase his ability to test and assess character, as well as his skill in diplomacy and negotiation.

plots.name: Margaery Tyrell
plots.description: The new queen, recently married to Joffrey.
plots.summary: Margaery plays her role as the beautiful and charming new queen, winning over the crowd and seeming to manage Joffrey's temperament.

Margaery Tyrell.profile:
Margaery Tyrell emerges as a pivotal figure in "A Storm of Swords," the third installment of George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A scion of House Tyrell, Margaery is introduced as the newly crowned queen of the Seven Kingdoms, having recently wed King Joffrey Baratheon. Her physical beauty is matched by her political acumen and charm, traits that prove invaluable in navigating the treacherous waters of King's Landing.

Margaery's character is defined by her ability to adapt and thrive in the complex political landscape of Westeros. She demonstrates a remarkable talent for public relations, effortlessly winning over the common people and courtiers alike with her grace and apparent kindness. This charisma is particularly evident during her wedding to Joffrey, where she manages to captivate the crowd and present herself as the ideal queen.

Perhaps Margaery's most notable attribute is her skill in managing the volatile King Joffrey. Where others have failed to temper his cruel tendencies, Margaery appears to have a calming influence on the young king, at least in public settings. This ability suggests a deep understanding of power dynamics and human psychology, which she leverages to secure her position and advance her family's interests.

While Margaery's inner thoughts and true motivations remain largely obscured, her actions paint a picture of a shrewd and ambitious young woman. She seems to understand that her role as queen is not just ceremonial, but a position of significant influence that can be used to shape the realm. Her marriage to Joffrey represents a major plot point, solidifying the alliance between Houses Lannister and Tyrell and shifting the balance of power in Westeros.

Throughout the story, Margaery's character serves as a foil to other players in the game of thrones, particularly in contrast to the more openly manipulative or brutal tactics employed by others. Her approach to power is more subtle, relying on charm, diplomacy, and carefully cultivated public image to achieve her goals.

As "A Storm of Swords" unfolds, Margaery Tyrell stands as a testament to the power of soft influence in a world often dominated by brute force and overt scheming. Her presence adds layers of complexity to the political landscape of Westeros, making her a character of significant interest and importance in the ongoing saga.

plots.name: Marillion
plots.description: A singer favored by Lady Lysa Arryn.
plots.summary: Escorts Sansa to the High Hall, making her uncomfortable with his behavior and comments.

utterances.message: [We need practical information.] What do we know of Stark's plans and movements?

Mathis Rowan.profile:
Mathis Rowan is a minor but notable character in "A Storm of Swords," serving as a member of the small council in King's Landing. As Lord of Goldengrove and head of House Rowan, he represents one of the powerful noble families of the Reach. Rowan's presence on the small council indicates his political importance and loyalty to the crown during the War of the Five Kings.

While not extensively detailed in the narrative, Rowan's contributions to council meetings reveal him to be a pragmatic and level-headed advisor. His focus on gathering practical information about enemy movements, as demonstrated by his inquiry about Robb Stark's plans, suggests a strategic mind and a concern for the realm's military situation.

Rowan's position on the small council places him in the midst of the political machinations of figures like Tywin Lannister, Petyr Baelish, and Varys. Though he doesn't dominate discussions, his input is valued, and he appears to be a stabilizing presence among the more volatile personalities in the capital.

As a lord from the Reach, Rowan likely maintains connections with House Tyrell, though his individual ambitions and loyalties beyond service to the crown are not explicitly explored in the provided context. His role in the story primarily serves to flesh out the political landscape of Westeros and provide additional perspective on the strategic decisions made during the ongoing conflicts.

plots.name: Meera Reed
plots.description: Jojen's older sister, a skilled hunter and protector of the group.
plots.summary: Meera provides food for the group and helps maintain a positive atmosphere despite their challenging circumstances.

plots.name: Meera Reed
plots.description: A crannogwoman accompanying Bran on his journey.
plots.summary: Meera hunts for food, helps guide the group, and tells Bran the story of the Knight of the Laughing Tree.

plots.name: Meera Reed
plots.description: A young crannogwoman, sister of Jojen.
plots.summary: Meera scouts ahead for the group, helps them enter the tower, and tries to reassure Bran when men are spotted in the village.

plots.name: Meera Reed
plots.description: A young crannogwoman, sister of Jojen.
plots.summary: Meera tries to keep everyone calm and assess their defensive options in the tower.

conversations.name: Meera Reed
conversations.thought: I need to lift everyone's spirits with a good story. This tale of the Knight of the Laughing Tree might intrigue Bran and offer some hidden truths about his family's past. I must be careful in how I present it, balancing entertainment with subtle revelation.

conversations.name: Meera Reed
conversations.thought: We're in a precarious position, but we've overcome challenges before. My priority is protecting Bran and keeping everyone calm. I need to assess our defenses and possible escape routes. Jojen seems more anxious than usual – what has he seen? I must stay alert and ready for anything.

conversations.name: Meera Reed
conversations.thought: I'm on high alert, ready to defend the group if necessary. Bran's growing abilities worry me, especially their effect on Hodor. I'm torn between protecting my brother Jojen and fulfilling our mission to guide Bran. The armed men outside are a immediate threat, and I'm assessing every possible escape route. I feel the weight of being the group's primary protector.

utterances.message: [I know just the story to tell.] Oh, a few.
[I should correct Jojen's statement.] Above the water. The bogs are full of dead ones, though.

[I'll start with the introduction to capture Bran's interest.] Once there was a curious lad who lived in the Neck. He was small like all crannogmen, but brave and smart and strong as well. He grew up hunting and fishing and climbing trees, and learned all the magics of my people.

[I should clarify the character's abilities.] No, but he could breathe mud and run on leaves, and change earth to water and water to earth with no more than a whispered word. He could talk to trees and weave words and make castles appear and disappear.
[I should tease Bran a little to keep him interested.] (makes a face at Bran) Sooner if a certain prince would be quiet.
[Is it just the man from before?] The man we saw earlier?
[We need more information to assess the threat.] How many?
[Perhaps they're not as mobile as I feared.] Mounted?
[I need to reassure Bran and keep everyone calm.] They won't. (She sits beside Bran) Why should they?
[I've already considered our defenses.] I couldn't even close it. The wood's too warped. They won't get past those iron gates, though.
[We must calm Hodor before he alerts the men outside.] (She tries to catch and calm Hodor, but he's too strong)
[I'm concerned for both Bran and Hodor.] (She looks worriedly between Bran and Hodor) Are you both alright?
[We need a plan.] Could we slip away in the night? If they don't know we're here, we might be able to avoid them entirely.
[That's a good idea, but I'm worried.] It's risky, Bran. If they spot Summer, they might come investigate.
[I need to be ready for anything.] (She grips her frog spear tightly, watching Bran and keeping an ear out for any sounds from outside)
[We need to act fast.] (Her voice is tense) We have to leave. Now. While it's still dark.

Meera Reed.profile:
Meera Reed is a resourceful and loyal crannogwoman from the Neck, introduced in "A Storm of Swords" as a key companion to Bran Stark on his perilous journey north. As the older sister of Jojen Reed, Meera embodies the unique traits of her people: she is agile, skilled in hunting and survival, and possesses a deep connection to the natural world.

Physically adept and quick-witted, Meera serves as both protector and provider for her small group of travelers. Her prowess with a frog spear and net showcases her upbringing in the swamps of the Neck, while her ability to forage and hunt in harsh conditions proves invaluable during their trek through the northern wilderness.

Meera's personality is marked by a blend of pragmatism and compassion. She maintains a level head in dangerous situations, often being the voice of reason and strategy within the group. Her protective instincts extend not only to her prophetic brother Jojen but also to Bran and Hodor, demonstrating her strong sense of duty and loyalty.

Throughout their journey, Meera plays a crucial role in keeping the group's spirits up, often through storytelling. Her recounting of the tale of the Knight of the Laughing Tree serves both to entertain Bran and subtly reveal important historical information, highlighting her intelligence and understanding of the power of stories.

As the group faces increasing dangers, such as the threat of discovery by armed men, Meera's quick thinking and combat readiness come to the fore. She assesses defensive options, considers escape routes, and remains vigilant in the face of potential attacks, embodying the role of the group's primary protector.

Meera's relationship with Bran is complex, blending caretaker, friend, and guide. She supports his growing warging abilities while also expressing concern for the implications of his powers, particularly when Bran accidentally wargs into Hodor.

Throughout "A Storm of Swords," Meera Reed emerges as a vital and multifaceted character, her skills and determination proving essential to Bran Stark's survival and the unfolding of his destiny.

plots.name: Melisandre
plots.description: The Red Priestess, advisor to Stannis Baratheon.
plots.summary: Though not directly present, Melisandre's influence over Stannis and the events at Dragonstone is a central point of discussion and motivation for Davos.

plots.name: Melisandre
plots.description: A red priestess of R'hllor, advisor to Stannis Baratheon.
plots.summary: Melisandre visits Davos in his cell, attempting to convert him to her faith and hinting at her visions in the flames.

plots.name: Melisandre
plots.description: A red priestess of R'hllor and advisor to Stannis.
plots.summary: Melisandre warns of more false kings to come and urges Stannis to show the realm a sign of his power.

plots.name: Melisandre
plots.description: A priestess of R'hllor and advisor to Stannis Baratheon.
plots.summary: Melisandre accompanies Jon to meet with Stannis, demonstrating her influence and closeness to the king.

conversations.name: Melisandre
conversations.thought: Confident in her powers and the righteousness of her cause, Melisandre sees Davos as a potential convert and ally. She's determined to sway him to R'hllor's side, believing it crucial for Stannis' success. Her mind is filled with visions from the flames, driving her to spread her faith and prepare for the great war she foresees.

conversations.name: Melisandre
conversations.thought: Melisandre is focused on the mystical implications of recent events. She's eager to convince Stannis to embrace his role as Azor Ahai and demonstrate his power. She's also concerned about future threats she's foreseen, feeling a sense of urgency to guide Stannis's actions.

conversations.name: Melisandre
conversations.thought: Jon Snow's role in the greater conflict is yet to be revealed, but I sense his importance. I must observe keenly, looking for signs that confirm my visions. His connection to the North and the wildlings could be significant in the war to come. I'll advise Stannis based on what I discern from this encounter.

utterances.message: [I must make him understand the power of R'hllor.] This is a bad place, is it not? A dark place, and foul. The good sun does not shine here, nor the bright moon. (She lifts her hand toward the torch) This is all that stands between you and the darkness, Onion Knight. This little fire, this gift of R'hllor. Shall I put it out?
[He fears the darkness, as he should.] (smiles) So you have come to love the fire, it would seem.
[I must make him see the truth.] I am like this torch, Ser Davos. We are both instruments of R'hllor. We were made for a single purpose—to keep the darkness at bay. Do you believe that?

[He still doesn't understand.] Is the brave Ser Onions so frightened of a passing shadow? Take heart, then. Shadows only live when given birth by light, and the king's fires burn so low I dare not draw off any more to make another son. It might well kill him.

[His stubbornness is frustrating, but I must persist.] They did not protect Guncer Sunglass. He prayed thrice each day, and bore seven seven-pointed stars upon his shield, but when R'hllor reached out his hand his prayers turned to screams, and he burned. Why cling to these false gods?

[I must make him see the truth of the world.] The war has been waged since time began, and before it is done, all men must choose where they will stand. On one side is R'hllor, the Lord of Light, the Heart of Fire, the God of Flame and Shadow. Against him stands the Great Other whose name may not be spoken, the Lord of Darkness, the Soul of Ice, the God of Night and Terror. Ours is not a choice between Baratheon and Lannister, between Greyjoy and Stark. It is death we choose, or life. Darkness, or light.
[I must guide Stannis to see the truth of R'hllor's power.] R'hllor chooses such instruments as he requires. His ways are mysterious, but no man may withstand his fiery will.
[I must warn him of the dangers I've seen in the flames.] I am sorry, Your Grace. This is not an end. More false kings will soon rise to take up the crowns of those who've died.

Melisandre.profile:
Melisandre, known as the Red Priestess, is a mysterious and powerful figure in "A Storm of Swords." Hailing from distant lands, she serves as a key advisor to Stannis Baratheon in his quest for the Iron Throne. With her striking appearance - fiery red hair and eyes that seem to glow - Melisandre cuts an imposing figure, inspiring both awe and fear in those around her.

As a devoted priestess of R'hllor, the Lord of Light, Melisandre's core motivation is to spread her faith and prepare the realm for a great war between light and darkness. She believes Stannis to be Azor Ahai reborn, a prophesied hero destined to combat an impending threat. This conviction drives her actions and counsel, often pushing Stannis towards bold and controversial decisions.

Melisandre possesses formidable magical abilities, including the power to see visions in flames and create shadow assassins. These powers, while potent, come at a great cost and are not without limitations. Her faith in R'hllor is absolute, and she views the world in stark terms of light versus darkness, life versus death.

Throughout the story, Melisandre's influence over Stannis grows, causing tension among his advisors. She attempts to convert others to her faith, as seen in her interactions with Davos Seaworth during his imprisonment. Her unwavering belief in her visions and interpretations often puts her at odds with more pragmatic counselors.

Melisandre's character arc revolves around her increasing involvement in Stannis's campaign and the moral ambiguity of her actions. While she genuinely believes in Stannis's cause and the greater good she serves, her methods are often ruthless and controversial, blurring the lines between ally and antagonist.

As events unfold, Melisandre continues to play a crucial role in shaping Stannis's strategies and the overall narrative, her prophecies and powers adding an element of mysticism and uncertainty to the political machinations of Westeros.

plots.name: Merrett Frey
plots.description: A member of House Frey, tasked with ransoming Petyr Pimple.
plots.summary: Merrett reflects on his past failures and current precarious position within House Frey as he embarks on a dangerous mission to ransom Petyr Pimple from outlaws.

Merrett Frey.profile:
Merrett Frey is a minor character in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords," the third book in the "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. As a member of House Frey, Merrett is one of the many sons of Lord Walder Frey, though he is not particularly distinguished or highly regarded within his family. Merrett's most notable characteristic is his constant headaches, which he attributes to a childhood injury and frequently uses as an excuse to avoid responsibilities.

Merrett's role in the story is primarily connected to the infamous Red Wedding, though he was not directly involved in the massacre itself. In the aftermath of this event, he is tasked with ransoming a captive from the Brotherhood Without Banners, a group of outlaws. This mission proves to be Merrett's undoing, as he encounters Lady Stoneheart, the resurrected Catelyn Stark, who is now leading the Brotherhood and seeking vengeance against those responsible for the Red Wedding.

Merrett's brief appearance in the story serves to illustrate the far-reaching consequences of the Freys' betrayal and the relentless pursuit of revenge by those they wronged. His encounter with Lady Stoneheart and subsequent execution highlight the ongoing fallout from the Red Wedding and the bleak fate awaiting many of those associated with House Frey.

plots.name: Oberyn Martell
plots.description: Prince of Dorne, known as the Red Viper, representing his brother Prince Doran.
plots.summary: Oberyn arrives in King's Landing with a large retinue, displaying a provocative and potentially dangerous presence. He engages Tyrion in conversation, hinting at their past meeting.

plots.name: Oberyn Martell
plots.description: Prince of Dorne, known as the Red Viper, representing his brother Prince Doran.
plots.summary: Oberyn arrives in King's Landing with a large retinue, displaying a provocative and potentially dangerous presence. He engages Tyrion in conversation, hinting at their past meeting.

plots.name: Oberyn Martell
plots.description: Prince of Dorne, one of the judges at Tyrion's trial.
plots.summary: Visits Tyrion in his cell, discussing the trial, potential political maneuvers, and hinting at his own motivations regarding the Lannisters.

plots.name: Oberyn Martell
plots.description: The Red Viper of Dorne, fighting as Tyrion's champion.
plots.summary: Oberyn fights with skill and speed, repeatedly accusing Gregor of his sister's murder while avoiding the Mountain's attacks.

conversations.name: Oberyn Martell
conversations.thought: This dwarf represents the Lannisters, the family I hold responsible for my sister's fate. I'll play the diplomatic game for now, but my true purpose here goes beyond mere pleasantries. I must assess the political landscape, gather information, and find a way to pursue justice for Elia. Every word and gesture from the Lannisters will be scrutinized.

conversations.name: Oberyn Martell
conversations.thought: This dwarf represents the Lannisters, the family I hold responsible for my sister's fate. I'll play the diplomatic game for now, but my true purpose here goes beyond mere pleasantries. I must assess the political landscape, gather information, and find a way to pursue justice for Elia. Every word and gesture from the Lannisters will be scrutinized.

conversations.name: Oberyn Martell
conversations.thought: This visit serves multiple purposes. I'm curious about Tyrion's true involvement in Joffrey's death, but more importantly, I see an opportunity to further my own agenda against the Lannisters. Tyrion's predicament could be useful. I'll probe his mental state, gauge his willingness to form alliances, and perhaps drop hints about my own intentions. All while maintaining an air of casual indifference to mask my true objectives.

conversations.name: Oberyn Martell
conversations.thought: Years of waiting have led to this moment. I must expose Clegane's crimes and avenge Elia. My spear and agility are my advantages, but I cannot underestimate his strength. I'll torment him with words as much as with my weapon. Justice for Elia, her children, and all of Dorne rests on my shoulders.

utterances.message: [He knows very well Doran isn't here. Let's see how he handles this.] (removes his helm) My brother's health requires he remain at Sunspear. Prince Doran has sent me to join King Joffrey's council in his stead, as it please His Grace.

[Let's see how he reacts to our full company.] (gestures to his companions) Permit me to acquaint you with them, my lord of Lannister. (proceeds to introduce each member of his party, including his paramour)
[Time to rattle the Imp a bit.] (rides beside Tyrion) We have met before. I would not expect you to remember, though. You were even smaller than you are now.

[Let's see how much he knows about that visit.] Oh, many and many a year ago, when my mother ruled in Dorne and your lord father was Hand to a different king. It was when I visited Casterly Rock with my mother, her consort, and my sister Elia.

[He knows very well Doran isn't here. Let's see how he handles this.] (removes his helm) My brother's health requires he remain at Sunspear. Prince Doran has sent me to join King Joffrey's council in his stead, as it please His Grace.

[Let's see how he reacts to our full company.] (gestures to his companions) Permit me to acquaint you with them, my lord of Lannister. (proceeds to introduce each member of his party, including his paramour)
[Time to rattle the Imp a bit.] (rides beside Tyrion) We have met before. I would not expect you to remember, though. You were even smaller than you are now.

[Let's see how much he knows about that visit.] Oh, many and many a year ago, when my mother ruled in Dorne and your lord father was Hand to a different king. It was when I visited Casterly Rock with my mother, her consort, and my sister Elia.
[I'll assert my authority while maintaining a casual demeanor.] Princes are permitted to go where they will. Or so I told your guards.
[I care little for Tywin's opinions.] The happiness of Tywin Lannister has never been high on my list of concerns. Is it Dornish wine you're drinking?
[I'll use this to subtly bring up the topic of poison.] Red water. Did you poison him?
[His quick wit amuses me, but I must remind him of the danger he's in.] Do all dwarfs have tongues like yours? Someone is going to cut it out one of these days.
[Time to change the subject and reveal some information.] I have turned up that golden-haired whore I was hoping for.

[I'll clarify my meaning and gauge his reaction.] At Chataya's I bedded the black-skinned girl. Alayaya, I believe she is called. Exquisite, despite the stripes on her back. But the whore I referred to is your sister.
[I must unsettle him from the start.] Have they told you who I am?
[He's as brutal and stupid as they say. Good.] I am Oberyn Martell, a prince of Dorne. Princess Elia was my sister.
[His ignorance fuels my rage.] (thrusts his spear) Elia Martell, Princess of Dorne. You raped her. You murdered her. You killed her children.
[I'll make him confess before he dies.] I came to hear you confess. (lands a thrust on Gregor's belly)
[He's losing his composure. Good.] You raped her. You murdered her. You killed her children.

Oberyn Martell.profile:
Oberyn Martell, known as the Red Viper, is a charismatic and dangerous prince of Dorne who arrives in King's Landing as a key player in the political landscape of Westeros. Representing his brother, Prince Doran, Oberyn's presence is both provocative and potentially destabilizing. With a reputation for skill in combat, poison use, and a penchant for sensuality, Oberyn cuts a striking figure in the capital.

Physically, Oberyn is described as a handsome man with a lined face, dark eyes, and salt-and-pepper hair. His movements are graceful and purposeful, befitting his reputation as a deadly warrior. Oberyn's personality is marked by his sharp wit, boldness, and an underlying current of simmering rage directed at the Lannisters.

At the core of Oberyn's motivations lies a deep-seated desire for vengeance against those responsible for the rape and murder of his sister, Elia Martell, and her children during Robert's Rebellion. This drive for justice shapes his actions and decisions throughout his time in King's Landing.

Oberyn's relationships are complex and multifaceted. He travels with his paramour, openly flouting conventional morality, and displays a keen understanding of political maneuvering. His interactions with Tyrion Lannister are particularly noteworthy, as he serves as both a judge in Tyrion's trial and later as his champion in trial by combat.

The prince's arc culminates in a dramatic trial by combat against Ser Gregor Clegane, the man believed to have killed Elia. In this fight, Oberyn's skill with a spear and his quick movements are on full display, as is his determination to extract a confession from his opponent. His repeated accusation, "You raped her. You murdered her. You killed her children," becomes a haunting refrain that underscores the depth of his quest for vengeance.

Oberyn Martell's presence in King's Landing serves as a catalyst for significant plot developments, bringing Dornish interests to the forefront of the political landscape and adding a new dimension to the ongoing power struggles in the capital. His character embodies the themes of revenge, justice, and the far-reaching consequences of past atrocities that permeate the series.

utterances.message: [I should show enthusiasm for our victories.] Gods be praised! A great victory for King Joffrey!

Paxter Redwyne.profile:
Paxter Redwyne is a minor yet notable character in "A Storm of Swords," serving as a member of the small council in King's Landing. As the Lord of the Arbor, he represents one of the most powerful houses in the Reach, known for their vast fleet and fine wines. Paxter's presence on the council underscores the Tyrell alliance with the Lannisters following the Battle of the Blackwater.

Though not extensively developed in the narrative, Paxter's character is revealed through his interactions during council meetings. He demonstrates a tendency to offer enthusiastic support for the crown's victories, as evidenced by his exclamation, "Gods be praised! A great victory for King Joffrey!" This behavior suggests a desire to curry favor with the ruling faction and maintain his position of influence.

Paxter's role on the small council primarily involves providing input on matters of war strategy and political alliances. His contributions, while not always substantial, reflect his vested interest in the realm's stability and the Lannister-Tyrell partnership. As a seasoned lord and commander of a significant naval force, his presence adds weight to the council's decisions, particularly those involving maritime affairs or trade.

While Paxter Redwyne does not drive major plot points in "A Storm of Swords," his character serves to illustrate the complex web of alliances and power dynamics at play in the governance of the Seven Kingdoms. His loyalty to the crown and his house's significant resources make him a valuable, if somewhat sycophantic, ally to the Lannister regime.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: Master of Coin, cunning and ambitious.
plots.summary: Proposes to marry Lysa Arryn to bring the Vale under control, showcasing his political maneuvering.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: A cunning nobleman, also known as Littlefinger.
plots.summary: Baelish orchestrates Sansa's escape, revealing himself as the mastermind behind the plan. He has Dontos killed to ensure secrecy.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: Cunning and ambitious, now Lord of Harrenhal and soon-to-be Lord Protector of the Vale.
plots.summary: Orchestrates his marriage to Lysa Arryn, continues to manipulate events and people around him, and maintains his facade of caring for Sansa.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: Lord Protector of the Vale, married to Lysa Arryn.
plots.summary: Helps Sansa build the snow castle, kisses her unexpectedly, and assists when Lord Robert has a seizure.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: A cunning nobleman, now married to Lysa Arryn and acting as Lord Protector of the Vale.
plots.summary: Petyr helps Sansa build the snow castle, then unexpectedly kisses her, causing her confusion and distress.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: Also known as Littlefinger, a cunning and ambitious man.
plots.summary: Petyr manipulates the situation, calming Lysa only to murder her by pushing her through the Moon Door, showcasing his ruthlessness and duplicity.

conversations.name: Petyr Baelish
conversations.thought: This is my moment to advance my position significantly. My proposal to deal with the Vale is bold, but calculated. I must present it persuasively, anticipating and countering any objections. While appearing to serve the crown's interests, this move will primarily serve my own. I'm prepared to outmaneuver any opposition, particularly from the ever-observant Tyrion.

conversations.name: Petyr Baelish
conversations.thought: I must handle this delicately. Sansa is crucial to my plans, and I need her to trust me completely. I'll have to balance honesty with manipulation, revealing enough to gain her confidence while maintaining control. It's time to shatter her illusions and show her the harsh realities of the game we're playing.

conversations.name: Petyr Baelish
conversations.thought: I must carefully craft Sansa's new identity to protect her and further my plans. She's a valuable asset, but naive. I need to guide her firmly while maintaining her trust and dependence on me. This conversation is crucial for her survival and my schemes.

conversations.name: Petyr Baelish
conversations.thought: Seeing Sansa alone presents an perfect opportunity to further my plans. I must balance my genuine attraction to her with my long-term schemes. My goal is to gain her trust and affection, using this moment of vulnerability to my advantage. I'll offer help and share memories to create a bond, all while gauging her reactions for future manipulation.

conversations.name: Petyr Baelish
conversations.thought: Seeing Sansa alone is the perfect chance to deepen our connection. I must tread carefully, balancing between gaining her trust and pursuing my own desires. My ultimate goal remains unclear even to me, but I know Sansa is key. I'll use my charm and knowledge to impress her, perhaps even push boundaries to gauge her reaction.

conversations.name: Petyr Baelish
conversations.thought: I must navigate this delicate situation carefully. Lysa's instability is both a threat and an opportunity. My primary goal is to protect Sansa while maintaining control. I'll need to manipulate Lysa's emotions and use her trust in me to defuse this crisis. Whatever the outcome, I must ensure it serves my long-term plans.

utterances.message: [I must remind them of the bigger picture.] A terrible defeat for the north, certainly, yet one in which Robb Stark played no part. The Young Wolf remains unbeaten in the field.

[Now is my moment to shine.] My lords, with your leave, I propose to travel to the Vale and there woo and win Lady Lysa Arryn. Once I am her consort, I shall deliver you the Vale of Arryn without a drop of blood being spilled.
[Tyrion, you fool, you're playing right into my hands.] (smiles) My little friend is too kind. All I do is count coppers, as King Robert used to say. Any clever tradesman could do as well...
[I must be gentle yet firm with her. She needs to understand the reality of the situation.] My lady, your grief is wasted on such a man as that. He was a sot, and no man's friend.

[I need to reveal the truth to her, no matter how harsh.] He sold you for a promise of ten thousand dragons. Your disappearance will make them suspect you in Joffrey's death. The gold cloaks will hunt, and the eunuch will jingle his purse. Dontos... well, you heard him. He sold you for gold, and when he'd drunk it up he would have sold you again. A bag of dragons buys a man's silence for a while, but a well-placed quarrel buys it forever.

[I must show her that I've been protecting her all along.] (smiles sadly) All he did he did at my behest. I dared not befriend you openly. When I heard how you saved his life at Joff's tourney, I knew he would be the perfect catspaw.
[I need to remind her of our past interaction, to show her I've always been honest with her.] Do you perchance recall what I said to you that day your father sat the Iron Throne?
[I see her tears and know she's beginning to understand. I must be her rock now.] (gently) Come, my lady. You're safe now, and that's what matters most. We have much to discuss about your future.

[I need to impress upon her the gravity of the situation.] Varys has informers everywhere. If Sansa Stark should be seen in the Vale, the eunuch will know within a moon's turn, and that would create unfortunate . . . complications. It is not safe to be a Stark just now. So we shall tell Lysa's people that you are my natural daughter.
[Her naivety is both endearing and frustrating.] Well, you can scarcely be my trueborn daughter. I've never taken a wife, that's well known. What should you be called?
[I need to steer her away from obvious connections.] Catelyn? A bit too obvious . . . but after my mother, that would serve. Alayne. Do you like it?

[Her suggestion is naive, but I must be patient.] I have no gallant knights in my service, Alayne. Such a tale would draw unwanted questions as a corpse draws crows. It is rude to pry into the origins of a man's natural children, however. (pauses) So, who are you?
[I'll test her reaction.] Kella?

[Her reaction amuses me, but I'll provide a more suitable story.] I was teasing. Your mother was a gentlewoman of Braavos, daughter of a merchant prince. We met in Gulltown when I had charge of the port. She died giving you birth, and entrusted you to the Faith. I have some devotional books you can look over. Learn to quote from them. Nothing discourages unwanted questions as much as a flow of pious bleating.
[I need to offer assistance without seeming too eager.] Pack the snow around a stick, Sansa. (approaches the snow castle)
That will give it strength enough to stand, I'd think. May I come into your castle, my lady?
...gentle? (smiles) Winterfell has withstood fiercer enemies than me. It is Winterfell, is it not?
[This is my chance to connect with her through shared memories.] I used to dream of it, in those years after Cat went north with Eddard Stark. In my dreams it was ever a dark place, and cold.

[This is perfect. I can show her how helpful I can be.] The glass was locked in frames, no? Twigs are your answer. Peel them and cross them and use bark to tie them together into frames. I'll show you. (begins gathering materials)
[Now's my chance.] (touches her face) And so is that.
Your smile, my lady. Shall I make another for you?
[She's not resisting. I can push further.] Nothing could please me more. (moves closer)
[I need to gain her trust and affection.] (approaches Sansa) Pack the snow around a stick, Sansa. That will give it strength enough to stand, I'd think. May I come into your castle, my lady?
[She's still cautious around me. I need to put her at ease.] (smiles) Winterfell has withstood fiercer enemies than me. It is Winterfell, is it not?
[I can use this moment to create a connection with her.] I used to dream of it, in those years after Cat went north with Eddard Stark. In my dreams it was ever a dark place, and cold.

[This is my chance to impress her with my knowledge and helpfulness.] (strokes his chin) The glass was locked in frames, no? Twigs are your answer. Peel them and cross them and use bark to tie them together into frames. I'll show you.
[Now's the moment to make my move.] (touches Sansa's face) And so is that.
[She's innocent, but I must push forward.] Your smile, my lady. Shall I make another for you?
[She's receptive. I can take this further.] Nothing could please me more. (moves closer)
[This is my chance.] (suddenly kisses Sansa)
[I need to play this off casually.] (straightens his cloak) Kissing a snow maid.
[I need to assess the situation quickly and take control.] Lysa! What's the meaning of this? (He approaches cautiously) Get back from there! Lysa, what are you doing?
[I need to calm Lysa down and gain control of the situation.] She's a child, Lysa. Cat's daughter. What did you think you were doing?
[I need to play this carefully to manipulate Lysa's emotions.] I see. (He strokes his chin) I think she understands now. Isn't that so, Alayne?
[I see an opportunity to further manipulate Lysa.] We'll send her away, then. Back to King's Landing, if you like. (He takes a step toward them) Let her up, now. Let her away from the door.

[I need to soothe her and get her away from Sansa.] That's past and done, Lysa. Lord Hoster's dead, and his old maester as well. (He moves closer) Have you been at the wine again? You ought not to talk so much. We don't want Alayne to know more than she should, do we?

[I see my chance to end this. I put on my most reassuring tone.] I know, love. (He takes another step) And I am here. All you need to do is take my hand, come on. (He holds it out to her) There's no cause for all these tears.

[It's time to end this charade. I put on my most loving expression.] Lysa, after all the storms we've suffered, you should trust me better. I swear, I shall never leave your side again, for as long as we both shall live.
[Now for the final act. I steel myself for what I must do.] Truly. Now unhand the girl and come give me a kiss.
[The time has come. I allow myself a moment of cold satisfaction.] My sweet silly jealous wife. (He chuckles) I've only loved one woman, I promise you.
[I savor this moment of triumph.] Only Cat. (He gives her a short, sharp shove)

Petyr Baelish.profile:
Petyr Baelish, also known as Littlefinger, is a cunning and ambitious nobleman in "A Storm of Swords." As the Master of Coin on the Small Council, he leverages his financial acumen and political savvy to advance his position in the tumultuous landscape of Westerosi politics. Baelish is characterized by his ability to manipulate events and people to his advantage, often operating behind the scenes to orchestrate complex schemes.

Physically unremarkable, Baelish's true power lies in his sharp intellect and silver tongue. He possesses an uncanny ability to anticipate and exploit the motivations of others, using this skill to climb the social and political ladder. His core motivation appears to be the accumulation of power and influence, driven by a desire to transcend his relatively modest origins.

Throughout the story, Baelish's actions significantly impact the plot. He proposes a strategic marriage to Lysa Arryn to bring the Vale under the crown's control, showcasing his political maneuvering. Later, he masterminds Sansa Stark's escape from King's Landing following Joffrey's assassination, revealing the extent of his long-term planning and willingness to eliminate loose ends, as demonstrated by his cold-blooded execution of Ser Dontos Hollard.

Baelish's relationship with Sansa Stark is particularly notable. He positions himself as her protector while simultaneously manipulating her for his own ends. His creation of a false identity for Sansa as his natural daughter, Alayne Stone, demonstrates both his quick thinking and his skill in navigating dangerous political waters.

As the story progresses, Baelish's machinations become increasingly complex and far-reaching. His marriage to Lysa Arryn and assumption of the title Lord Protector of the Vale mark significant advancements in his quest for power. Throughout these events, he maintains a facade of loyalty to the crown while pursuing his own agenda, embodying the intricate and treacherous nature of politics in the world of "A Song of Ice and Fire."

plots.name: Polliver
plots.description: One of Gregor Clegane's men, encountered at the inn.
plots.summary: Polliver engages in a fight with the Hound and is killed during the encounter.

conversations.name: Polliver
conversations.thought: The Hound is a traitor to the Lannisters. We should capture him for Ser Gregor. I'm curious about his companion and why he's here. I'll boast about our recent victories to intimidate him. If he makes a wrong move, we'll take him down.

utterances.message: [I need to confirm if this is really the Hound.] Looking for your brother, Sandor?
[I should inform him about recent events.] King Joffrey's dead, you know. Poisoned at his own wedding feast.
[I'll share the rumors I've heard.] The Imp, it's thought. Him and his little wife.

[I'll explain what I know.] I forgot, you've been hiding under a rock. The northern girl. Winterfell's daughter. We heard she killed the king with a spell, and afterward changed into a wolf with big leather wings like a bat, and flew out a tower window. But she left the dwarf behind and Cersei means to have his head.

[I'll boast about our success.] Didn't require much taking. The sellswords fled as soon as they knew we were coming, all but a few. One of the cooks opened a postern gate for us, to get back at Hoat for cutting off his foot. (He chuckles) We kept him to cook for us, a couple wenches to warm our beds, and put all the rest to the sword.
[I'll reveal more about our cruelty.] Well, Ser kept Hoat to pass the time.
[We must give praise to the Lord of Light for this victory.] Praise the Lord of Light!

Selyse Baratheon.profile:
Selyse Baratheon, born of House Florent, is the wife of Stannis Baratheon and Queen of the Seven Kingdoms by his claim. A stern and unyielding woman, Selyse is characterized by her fervent devotion to the Lord of Light, R'hllor, a faith she shares with the red priestess Melisandre. This religious zeal often puts her at odds with her husband's more pragmatic approach to governance and warfare.

Physically unremarkable and often described as unattractive, Selyse's most notable features are her prominent ears, a trait common to House Florent. Her appearance, however, is secondary to her fierce determination and unwavering belief in her husband's right to the Iron Throne.

Selyse's relationship with Stannis is complex and often strained. While she supports his claim wholeheartedly, their personal dynamic lacks warmth, partly due to their inability to produce a male heir. Their only child, Shireen, is afflicted with greyscale, which Selyse views as a mark of shame.

In "A Storm of Swords," Selyse's role is primarily supportive, echoing Melisandre's counsel and urging Stannis to embrace the power of R'hllor. During discussions of critical events like the Red Wedding, she is quick to attribute such occurrences to divine intervention, praising the Lord of Light for what she perceives as acts in favor of Stannis's cause.

Selyse's fervent religious beliefs sometimes lead her to make impractical suggestions, such as the need for dragons to secure Stannis's victory. This demonstrates her detachment from political realities and her tendency to rely on supernatural solutions to worldly problems.

Throughout the story, Selyse remains a steadfast, if somewhat marginalized, figure in Stannis's court. Her unwavering support for her husband and her religious convictions form the core of her character, even as her influence on major decisions remains limited. Her presence serves to highlight the tension between faith and pragmatism in Stannis's campaign for the Iron Throne.

plots.name: Qyburn
plots.description: A former maester now serving with the Brave Companions.
plots.summary: Qyburn treats Jaime's infected stump, preventing further damage but causing him great pain in the process.

Qyburn.profile:
Qyburn is an enigmatic and controversial figure in "A Storm of Swords," the third installment of George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A former maester stripped of his chain and title by the Citadel, Qyburn now serves with the Brave Companions, a notorious mercenary company. His appearance in the story is marked by his role as a skilled healer, though his methods and ethics are often questionable.

Qyburn's introduction comes at a critical moment, as he tends to Jaime Lannister's infected stump after the knight loses his sword hand. His medical expertise proves invaluable, as he manages to prevent further damage to Jaime's arm through painful but effective treatment. This encounter showcases Qyburn's practical skills and his willingness to employ unconventional methods to achieve results.

Despite his affiliation with the brutal Brave Companions, Qyburn displays a calm and professional demeanor in his work. His background as a maester hints at a vast knowledge of healing and possibly other arcane arts, though the reasons for his expulsion from the Citadel remain mysterious. This air of intrigue surrounding Qyburn's past and his current allegiances adds depth to his character and suggests there may be more to him than meets the eye.

Qyburn's role in treating Jaime Lannister marks the beginning of his involvement in the wider political landscape of Westeros, hinting at the potential for this enigmatic character to play a larger part in future events. His willingness to work with various factions and his unique set of skills make him a potentially valuable asset in the ongoing power struggles of the realm.

utterances.message: [The wolf is key to Jon's acceptance. I should mention it.] The lad's a warg, or close enough. His wolf took a piece o' Halfhand's leg.

Ragwyle.profile:
Ragwyle is a minor character in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords," the third book in the "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. She is a wildling woman who appears during Jon Snow's infiltration of the wildling camp led by Mance Rayder. While not extensively featured, Ragwyle plays a small but notable role in Jon's introduction to the wildling community.

As a wildling, Ragwyle is likely hardy and accustomed to the harsh life beyond the Wall. Her exact physical appearance is not detailed, but she likely shares the rugged characteristics common to the Free Folk. Ragwyle demonstrates a keen observation of Jon Snow's abilities, particularly his connection with his direwolf, Ghost.

In the crucial scene where Jon is presented to the wildling leadership, Ragwyle speaks up to highlight Jon's potential as a warg. Her statement, "The lad's a warg, or close enough. His wolf took a piece o' Halfhand's leg," shows her awareness of the value placed on skinchangers in wildling culture. This observation helps to establish Jon's credibility among the Free Folk and potentially saves his life by making him appear more valuable to Mance Rayder.

Ragwyle's role, while brief, contributes to the complex dynamics of Jon's precarious position among the wildlings. Her quick thinking and willingness to speak up demonstrate the collective nature of wildling decision-making and the importance of individual contributions within their society.

plots.name: Rattleshirt
plots.description: Also known as the Lord of Bones, a wildling leader escorting Jon to Mance Rayder.
plots.summary: Rattleshirt is suspicious of Jon and threatens him repeatedly, but leads the group to Mance Rayder's camp.

conversations.name: Rattleshirt
conversations.thought: This crow is more trouble than he's worth, but Mance will want to see him. I need to assert my authority and show I'm in control of this situation. If he makes one wrong move, I'll gladly add his bones to my armor. For now, I'll play up his importance to impress the Weeper.

utterances.message: [I'll show this Weeper I've got everything under control.] A crow come over. (shakes his sack of bones) He was afraid I'd take his bones as well as Halfhand's.
[I'll add to his accomplishments to make him seem more impressive.] And did for Orell too.
[Time to show this crow what he's in for.] We'll make camp here. Ygritte, Longspear, bring the crow so Mance can have his look. We'll gut him after.

Rattleshirt.profile:
Rattleshirt, also known as the Lord of Bones, is a formidable and intimidating wildling leader in George R.R. Martin's "A Storm of Swords." His distinctive appearance, characterized by armor adorned with the bones of his enemies, reflects his fierce and brutal nature. As a key figure among the Free Folk, Rattleshirt plays a significant role in escorting Jon Snow to Mance Rayder's camp, showcasing his position of authority and trust within the wildling hierarchy.

Rattleshirt's personality is marked by suspicion, aggression, and a penchant for threats. He maintains a constant air of hostility, particularly towards Jon Snow, whom he views as a potential threat despite the young man's supposed defection from the Night's Watch. This paranoia and readiness to violence are evident in his frequent menacing of Jon and his eagerness to "gut him" after presenting him to Mance Rayder.

Despite his brutish demeanor, Rattleshirt demonstrates a degree of cunning and political awareness. He recognizes the potential value of Jon Snow to Mance Rayder, skillfully presenting Jon's accomplishments to other wildling leaders like the Weeper to ensure Jon's passage to Mance. This behavior suggests that Rattleshirt, while primarily a warrior, understands the complexities of leadership and information brokering within the wildling society.

Rattleshirt's role in the story serves to illustrate the dangerous and unpredictable nature of the wildling forces that Jon Snow must navigate. His presence adds tension and conflict to Jon's journey, constantly testing the young man's ability to maintain his cover and survive among the Free Folk. Through Rattleshirt, readers gain insight into the harsh realities and power dynamics of life beyond the Wall, setting the stage for the larger conflict between the wildlings and the forces of Westeros.

plots.name: Robb Stark
plots.description: King in the North and of the Trident, son of Catelyn Stark.
plots.summary: Robb returns victorious from the west, forgives his mother for releasing Jaime Lannister, and shocks everyone by introducing his new wife, breaking a crucial alliance.

plots.name: Robb Stark
plots.description: King in the North, son of Catelyn.
plots.summary: Confronts Lord Karstark about the murders, struggling to maintain justice and control over his bannermen while dealing with the consequences of recent events.

plots.name: Robb Stark
plots.description: King in the North, seeking to make amends with the Freys.
plots.summary: Robb approaches the Twins with a mixture of confidence and caution, aware of the need to mend relations with the Freys while maintaining his royal dignity.

plots.name: Robb Stark
plots.description: King in the North, attending his uncle's wedding.
plots.summary: Robb is betrayed and killed by the Freys and Boltons during the wedding feast, shot with crossbow bolts and stabbed through the heart.

conversations.name: Robb Stark
conversations.thought: I'm relieved to see Mother safe, but her actions have put me in a difficult position. I must address her deeds while maintaining the respect of my bannermen. I want to forgive her, understanding her motivations, but I also need to appear strong and just as a king. This moment will test my ability to balance compassion with leadership.

conversations.name: Robb Stark
conversations.thought: I'm torn between pride in my recent victories and anxiety over the announcement I must make. I know my decision will have far-reaching consequences, potentially jeopardizing alliances. I'm steeling myself to face my mother's reaction, hoping she'll understand my choice. I'm determined to present a strong, kingly demeanor despite my inner turmoil.

conversations.name: Robb Stark
conversations.thought: I'm shocked and angered by this betrayal, but I must appear strong and in control. I need to deal with this firmly to uphold justice, yet I'm deeply concerned about the potential consequences for my campaign and alliances. I must make Lord Karstark see the dishonor in his actions while maintaining my authority as King in the North.

conversations.name: Robb Stark
conversations.thought: I know I've wronged the Freys, but I'm still their king. I must balance humility with authority, mending this crucial alliance without appearing weak. Mother's caution irks me, yet I can't ignore the palpable tension. I'll need all my political acumen to navigate this meeting successfully.

conversations.name: Robb Stark
conversations.thought: Pain and disbelief cloud my mind. I've been betrayed, my men are dying around me, and I can barely stand. The weight of my failure crushes me - I've led my people to their doom. My mother is trying to save me, but I fear it's too late. My thoughts turn to Jeyne, my wife, and Grey Wind, my direwolf. I must try to protect them, even in my final moments.

utterances.message: [I need to reassure her while maintaining my authority.] I took an arrow through the arm while storming the Crag. It's healed well, though. I had the best of care.
[I understand her motives, but I must be careful with my words.] For the girls.

[I must assert my authority and protect my mother.] Enough. No man calls my lady of Winterfell a traitor in my hearing, Lord Rickard. (Turns to Catelyn, softening his voice) If I could wish the Kingslayer back in chains I would. You freed him without my knowledge or consent... but what you did, I know you did for love. For Arya and Sansa, and out of grief for Bran and Rickon. Love's not always wise, I've learned. It can lead us to great folly, but we follow our hearts... wherever they take us. Don't we, Mother?

[I feel uncomfortable, knowing the impact of what I'm about to say.] Mother, may I present the Lady Sybell, the wife of Lord Gawen Westerling of the Crag. Her husband was one of those we took captive in the Whispering Wood.
[I continue the introductions, my nervousness growing.] (Introduces each Westerling in turn)
[I take a deep breath, knowing the weight of my next words.] Mother, I have the great honor to present you the Lady Jeyne Westerling. Lord Gawen's elder daughter, and my... ah... my lady wife.
[I must appear strong and in control, despite the shock and anger I feel.] Five. Is that all of them?
[I can't believe the scale of this betrayal.] (studying the faces of the captives) It required eight of you to kill two unarmed squires.

[I must make him see the dishonor in his actions.] I saw your sons die, that night in the Whispering Wood. Tion Frey did not kill Torrhen. Willem Lannister did not slay Eddard. How then can you call this vengeance? This was folly, and bloody murder. Your sons died honorably on a battlefield, with swords in their hands.
[I can't believe he's justifying the murder of children.] (pointing at the corpses) The blood of children? How old were they? Twelve, thirteen? Squires.
[I appreciate her concern, but I'm not a child anymore.] I know the Freys, Mother. I know how much I wronged them, and how much I need them. I shall be as sweet as a septon.
[I'm tired of being treated like a child.] I'm more wet than hungry...

[I'll humor her, but I think she's being overly cautious.] I have an army to protect me, Mother, I don't need to trust in bread and salt. But if it pleases Lord Walder to serve me stewed crow smothered in maggots, I'll eat it and ask for a second bowl.
[Stay diplomatic, stay calm.] The rains delayed us. I sent a bird.
[I can't let her sacrifice herself for me.] (in a whisper) No. Mother, no...
[Jeyne... my wife. But what about...] (struggling to stand) Mother, Grey Wind...

Robb Stark.profile:
Robb Stark, the Young Wolf and King in the North, is a central figure in "A Storm of Swords." The eldest son of Eddard and Catelyn Stark, Robb is thrust into leadership following his father's execution. As a young man barely out of boyhood, he demonstrates remarkable military prowess, leading his forces to several victories against the Lannisters.

Described as having the Tully coloring of his mother, with auburn hair and blue eyes, Robb embodies both the honor of the Starks and the fierce determination of youth. His direwolf, Grey Wind, serves as both a companion and a symbol of his connection to the North.

Robb's character is defined by his sense of duty, honor, and love for his family. These traits, while admirable, often lead him into difficult situations. His decision to marry Jeyne Westerling out of love and honor, breaking his betrothal to a Frey daughter, proves to be a critical mistake with far-reaching consequences.

As a leader, Robb shows a blend of compassion and justice. He forgives his mother for releasing Jaime Lannister, understanding her motivations, yet struggles with maintaining discipline among his bannermen, as seen in his confrontation with Lord Rickard Karstark over the murder of Lannister squires.

Robb's arc is one of tragic heroism. Despite his military successes, his political naivety and personal choices gradually undermine his cause. His attempt to mend relations with the Freys by attending his uncle Edmure's wedding leads to his downfall at the Red Wedding, where he is betrayed and killed alongside his mother and many of his men.

Throughout the story, Robb grapples with the weight of kingship, trying to balance his role as a leader with his personal desires and familial obligations. His journey highlights the harsh realities of war and politics in the world of Westeros, where honor and good intentions are often insufficient against treachery and ruthless ambition.

Robb Stark's legacy is one of unfulfilled potential and tragic loss, serving as a pivotal turning point in the war for the Iron Throne and leaving a lasting impact on the surviving characters and the political landscape of the Seven Kingdoms.

plots.name: Robert Arryn
plots.description: Young Lord of the Eyrie, Sansa's cousin and betrothed.
plots.summary: Destroys part of Sansa's snow castle and suffers a seizure when his doll is torn.

plots.name: Robert Arryn
plots.description: The young, sickly Lord of the Eyrie and Sansa's cousin.
plots.summary: Robert destroys part of Sansa's snow castle in a childish tantrum, leading to a seizure that requires medical attention.

Robert Arryn.profile:
Robert Arryn, also known as "Sweetrobin," is a young and sickly lord of the Vale in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. As the only child of Jon Arryn and Lysa Tully, he is the heir to the Eyrie and the nominal ruler of the Vale, though his mother acts as regent due to his young age and fragile health.

Physically frail and mentally underdeveloped for his age, Robert suffers from frequent seizures, which are referred to as "shaking sickness." His condition has led to overprotection from his mother, resulting in a stunted emotional growth and a lack of social skills. Robert is often described as small, pale, and sickly, with large eyes and fine brown hair.

Robert's personality is characterized by immaturity, neediness, and frequent tantrums. He displays an unhealthy attachment to his mother and a fondness for seeing people "fly" through the Moon Door, a feature of the Eyrie that opens to a steep drop. His behavior is largely influenced by his sheltered upbringing and his mother's indulgence.
